Objects are colour-coded based on their redshift range and match the colours used in the lower panels. The RGB colour image is generated from the MUSE data itself. Bottom: redshift distribution of all objects in the catalogue (for clarity, all members of a multiply imaged object are combined into a single entry). Colours are as follows: purple \u2013 stars (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0); blue \u2013 foreground galaxies (0 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.35); green \u2013 cluster galaxies (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4); yellow \u2013 \u2018near\u2019 background galaxies (0.4 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 1.5); orange \u2013 MUSE redshift desert (1.5 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 2.9); red \u2013 \u2018far\u2019 background galaxies (<em>z</em> &gt; 2.9). The colours and shading of the histogram bars are based on the spectral confidence value, as follows: plain bar \u2013 confidence 3 (high confidence); hashed bar \u2013 confidence 2 (medium confidence); grey bar \u2013 confidence 1 (low confidence). For complete spectral information, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a> and the <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online catalogue supplement</a></span>. Details of the spectral classification (including the confidence measurement) can be found in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">C</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We now describe portions of the redshift sample that are important for our subsequent lensing analysis, as well as a few additional objects that are interesting in their own right. We also compare our catalogue to the Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space (GLASS; Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), a programme providing catalogues of lower resolution near-IR spectroscopy of all six FF clusters. Given the higher sensitivity and resolution of MUSE relative to the <em>HST</em> grism, the number of objects with secure, high-confidence redshifts is significantly higher in our catalogue compared to that of GLASS, though we still find several objects in common between the two. While in most cases the GLASS catalogue agrees (within measurement uncertainty) with our updated MUSE results, there are some instances where MUSE is able to correct misidentified features in the GLASS data and provide a more accurate redshift for the object. Likewise, there are also instances where the presence of emission lines in the observed near-IR from GLASS improves the confidence of a redshift initially based on low-S/N features in the MUSE spectra. A summary of these comparisons can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblD1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblD1\" data-open=\"tblD1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D1</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763416 id=\"132763416\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-1>3.3.1 Multiply imaged systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">By covering nearly the entire multiple-image zone of A370 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) the new redshift catalogue contains a substantial number of lensing constraints that can significantly improve the overall mass model. Thanks to the deeper data in the cluster core, we are able to revise redshifts of previously known systems, while the wider coverage at larger distances allows us to confirm (or modify) counterimages missed in the GTO cube and identify entirely new systems located in different parts of the cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We begin by revisiting the lensing constraints used to construct the mass model presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> (hereafter referred to as the \u2018GTO model\u2019). Of the 22 multiple-image systems used in that work, only 4 (Systems 1, 2, 5, and 6) were completely contained within the GTO data, leading to secure spectroscopic redshifts for all images in the set. All other systems had at least one \u2018missed\u2019 counterimage lying beyond the MUSE footprint (identified only by lens-model predictions and HFF imaging), including six (Systems 3, 8, 10, 11, 12, and 13) that fell entirely outside of the cube. With our larger catalogue, we are able to examine the missed counterimages of the partial GTO systems, remarkably finding that (without exception) our model predictions are correct: We measure the expected redshifts in the mosaic at the same positions as the HFF imaging candidates. This showcases the predictive power of our initial lens model, and highlights the usefulness of even partial spectroscopic coverage. We note, however, that without the additional high-resolution imaging, our initial guesses would likely not have been as accurate.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, we provide new redshifts for many of the systems outside of the GTO cube and adjust the redshift of one GTO system that was too faint to be accurately measured. These updates are as follows. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 3: While this system was too far north to be seen in the GTO cube, Images 3.1 and 3.2 did have low-resolution grism spectroscopy from GLASS (Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>), and we used this redshift (<em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub>\u00a0= 1.95) in our earlier mass model. In the mosaic catalogue, we detect <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission in the central regions of these two images, giving rise to an updated redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.9553. More importantly, we modify the position of the third counterimage (Image 3.3), shifting it from the original galaxy identified in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to a nearby object slightly to the east (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>) based on the presence of faint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission in the new counterimage that does not appear in the original candidate. We note that this new result agrees with the prediction presented in Kawamata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a>), made without the use of other spectroscopic data.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 9: Although Image 9.1 fell inside the original GTO data set, the spectrum was too faint to measure any definitive lines. Therefore, like System 3, we relied on GLASS spectroscopy (<em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub>\u00a0= 1.52) for our previous mass model. With deeper mosaic data in the core, we are able to detect faint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission, leading to an improved redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.5182</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 10: We identify faint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] in Images 10.1 and 10.2, leading to a redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.7512. We also detect possible (though extremely weak; S/N \u223c 1.6) traces of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] in a separate counterimage (10.3; also predicted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>) at the same redshift. That this redshift is exactly the same as the one measured for System 7 brings up the intriguing possibility that both systems are in fact images of the same galaxy. We address this possibility in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 12: All images in this system show strong, broad Lyman\u2009\u03b1 absorption, along with other, narrower ultraviolet (UV) absorption features such as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small I}}$|</span>[\u03bb1301] and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{Si\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>[\u03bb1303]. Image 12.1 (which lies in the deeper\u2009central region of the mosaic) also shows faint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission, which we use to set the systemic velocity of the system (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.4809).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 13: Both original images in this system (Images 13.1 and 13.2) show strong Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission, resulting in a redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.2480. Furthermore, we also discover a faint counterimage (Image 13.3) in the south-west of the cluster with the same redshift, which has similar <em>HST</em> colours. While this new image is far from the prediction for 13.3 made with the GTO model, the lack of a secure redshift for the system in that model made an accurate guess more difficult.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems 8 and 11: Even with the new mosaic we are still unable to detect any features in spectra of Systems 8 and 11, though given their observed colours this is not entirely surprising. Photometric estimates for System 8 place it in the MUSE \u2018redshift desert\u2019 (<em>z</em> \u223c 1.5\u20133), where bright optical lines are too red to be observed, while Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission is still too blue. Although <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] can be used to measure redshifts in this range, we do not detect <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission in either of the known counterimages of this system. Conversely, the photometric redshift of System 11 (an <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> dropout galaxy) is <em>z</em> \u223c 7.8, suggesting it is too distant to be measured by MUSE. We do note, however, that thanks to the enhanced near-IR HFF coverage, we are able to identify a new counterimage with matching <em>HST</em> colours on the far-eastern side of the multiple-image region, which we use in subsequent mass modelling.</p></li></ul></p>                        <a id=\"132763420\" scrollto-destination=\"132763420\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=skCOoZ2BzZOLvHtaRhacHIkA4CWJDce496PWucnOMdrFLX-5Aeg8~hkEqmE-n8OhchStWWSTZgVBDFP-ZfHez2gk4~ZtzcHDHJ0NhYfWJl6WKQz5RFsyEP-MPLrq1ra44EG6NqzNH4W73XNDeUkkRFkq8iGWlrFF4KMGJ-fmqD~72sKW9ZAPQxkyBAGhxpJhUpmra8hM5SY5b~ja7a2QGuwXfJnHAi6EIYxVp2Hbf0uIXEEHrznbmFDKlfC5IGUdJq-c5TSyAEFjR2HWxjt~O538oIZKaGnNe4ux45UlWDv-fPnP6jh3zS-wNVnH5K1~OPOaW-secpn5JyH-mHnIXQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Updated configuration of System 3 (z\u00a0= 1.9553), including the new location of Image 3.3. We correct the position of Image 3.3 thanks to new spectroscopic and visual evidence: The $\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$] emission seen in the core of Images 3.1 and 3.2 is also found in the new counterimage (see Fig.\u00a0B1), but is absent in the old candidate (red circle). Additionally, the deeper near-IR HFF data show that the new counterimage has a pink colour (using an F814W, F105W, and F160W colour scheme) which better matches the core of the Image 3.1/3.2 pair.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763420/stz620fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763420\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=IMcjRTD-YFS9mHZp-cReqf3lIJLq4lrTNS~V4ceOzs~1FPnBUq5Ixim0Z4RYLgttbb7yQv22520nsecO7KSGtpwIax-3390qKlYOKPOEFK4RoYwYOr6GmGv~RDDsCwRFDY6yWrJXTXS~xfDIM-yuKHqLQI3dVIcXKQSWqgFY2o5by0I5XdWyYp85721qddrNNVRfAqoESLgOCHWfmamgOesB4DjR4gQ5nGueblOSbgT1NA1tUbv2KacPMWxT3bARKweVl0s3XRyroonn3NObHCcpO7WRzaa0pYlWQqFN9AYRdQqv9HyMaVCPKRj1Rmc7OiP0e1cktcLbGifU916gDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763420&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Updated configuration of System 3 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.9553), including the new location of Image 3.3. We correct the position of Image 3.3 thanks to new spectroscopic and visual evidence: The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission seen in the core of Images 3.1 and 3.2 is also found in the new counterimage (see Fig.\u00a0B1), but is absent in the old candidate (red circle). Additionally, the deeper near-IR HFF data show that the new counterimage has a pink colour (using an <em>F</em>814<em>W, F</em>105<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> colour scheme) which better matches the core of the Image 3.1/3.2 pair.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=skCOoZ2BzZOLvHtaRhacHIkA4CWJDce496PWucnOMdrFLX-5Aeg8~hkEqmE-n8OhchStWWSTZgVBDFP-ZfHez2gk4~ZtzcHDHJ0NhYfWJl6WKQz5RFsyEP-MPLrq1ra44EG6NqzNH4W73XNDeUkkRFkq8iGWlrFF4KMGJ-fmqD~72sKW9ZAPQxkyBAGhxpJhUpmra8hM5SY5b~ja7a2QGuwXfJnHAi6EIYxVp2Hbf0uIXEEHrznbmFDKlfC5IGUdJq-c5TSyAEFjR2HWxjt~O538oIZKaGnNe4ux45UlWDv-fPnP6jh3zS-wNVnH5K1~OPOaW-secpn5JyH-mHnIXQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Updated configuration of System 3 (z\u00a0= 1.9553), including the new location of Image 3.3. We correct the position of Image 3.3 thanks to new spectroscopic and visual evidence: The $\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$] emission seen in the core of Images 3.1 and 3.2 is also found in the new counterimage (see Fig.\u00a0B1), but is absent in the old candidate (red circle). Additionally, the deeper near-IR HFF data show that the new counterimage has a pink colour (using an F814W, F105W, and F160W colour scheme) which better matches the core of the Image 3.1/3.2 pair.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763420/stz620fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763420\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=IMcjRTD-YFS9mHZp-cReqf3lIJLq4lrTNS~V4ceOzs~1FPnBUq5Ixim0Z4RYLgttbb7yQv22520nsecO7KSGtpwIax-3390qKlYOKPOEFK4RoYwYOr6GmGv~RDDsCwRFDY6yWrJXTXS~xfDIM-yuKHqLQI3dVIcXKQSWqgFY2o5by0I5XdWyYp85721qddrNNVRfAqoESLgOCHWfmamgOesB4DjR4gQ5nGueblOSbgT1NA1tUbv2KacPMWxT3bARKweVl0s3XRyroonn3NObHCcpO7WRzaa0pYlWQqFN9AYRdQqv9HyMaVCPKRj1Rmc7OiP0e1cktcLbGifU916gDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763420&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Updated configuration of System 3 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.9553), including the new location of Image 3.3. We correct the position of Image 3.3 thanks to new spectroscopic and visual evidence: The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission seen in the core of Images 3.1 and 3.2 is also found in the new counterimage (see Fig.\u00a0B1), but is absent in the old candidate (red circle). Additionally, the deeper near-IR HFF data show that the new counterimage has a pink colour (using an <em>F</em>814<em>W, F</em>105<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> colour scheme) which better matches the core of the Image 3.1/3.2 pair.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">After making adjustments to the known constraints, we search for new multiply imaged objects in the field. While the larger mosaic makes finding these systems significantly easier than before \u2013 we simply identify groups of images that have the same redshift inside the multiple-image zone \u2013 we still use the GTO mass model as a guide. Specifically, we check that the observed image configuration of a candidate system is at least broadly consistent with its model prediction, to ensure that the targets are not simply a chance alignment of individual galaxies. While in principle we allow for a large separation (up to 10\u2009arcsec) between prediction and observation before rejecting the image \u2013 to avoid potentially biasing the new model \u2013 we note that none of the actual candidates deviate from their initial prediction by more than 3\u2009arcsec. At the same time, model predictions can also reveal additional counterimages missed by our spectroscopic campaign, either because they are too faint to be detected automatically or because they are highly contaminated by a nearby bright source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall, we identify 18 new systems with secure spectroscopic redshifts (labelled as Systems 23 through 40) in the MUSE data, with redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.9 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 6.3. This more than doubles the number of spectroscopically confirmed multiply imaged galaxies in A370, and considerably increases the total number of robust model constraints. Given their higher redshifts, many of these new images are located farther from the cluster centre than the GTO systems, providing better information about the A370 mass distribution out to larger radii. Most systems are identified by strong Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission (except System 38, which is instead a Lyman-break galaxy, identified by a prominent trough in the UV continuum), and while many are point-like, some do present features of extended emission \u2013 which is expected based on previous MUSE-based Lyman\u2009\u03b1 studies (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) This is especially apparent in the merging pair of System 24 and the large extended arc seen in System 29 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). Furthermore, the two most distant lensed galaxies are located beyond <em>z</em>\u00a0= 6 (System 35, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 6.1735; System 36, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 6.2855) \u2013 placing them close to the end of the epoch of reionization, possibly making them interesting objects for future study (e.g. Hern\u00e1n-Caballero et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"132763423\" scrollto-destination=\"132763423\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=WWMJERoV50LXiQFUUe2XJfjKaqog3Egma97gk1A8f5VOO4Rt3JxaGaOWXuysr4SPNULfmhK3p2qU6peYQJoaF5jYmqM07xTm0eIDEAN4k9-wmlV5omeVexC4ylFbpZ8EQXj~~h0eNa1Nf1i1RD904e54Ij4LoKfWBpNngK7BI6JrAzR0JcTOKSVGKj99CUnebw8Y5~WP1JLPTOUtUrlJuF714xs3gGC4toroDi3opy68gLSA~hmpDsi9GHe-LWhakh2TiWGmkc4guKYKFSh89muzlPA8UHnOCn~3IgSQMJ75oRdwETOYZiUtdChY~grb48QQ9M7Cy9ea3mSB1cHEMg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two examples of extended Lyman\u2009\u03b1 arcs found in the A370 MUSE mosaic: the merging pair System 24 (z\u00a0= 4.9160; cyan contours) and the giant arc System 29 (z\u00a0= 4.4897; green contours). In both cases the narrow-band Lyman\u2009\u03b1 flux is significantly larger than the observed continuum counterpart, highlighted by the magenta ellipses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763423/stz620fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=AAoaTZ~TnTPM485u5G2uKWT0F5hjrW5dxji8Ay~Trw~iKxergCleN~vvEoza1-xn2vgd9VlA014-V-B~QBU7Al72fOQGgBOZUk6W~jj6~7kO-5cHygWwH9Oj49DDwgxkeMW4EyONR3pF2J76XiJ79AUHXCd5OWWwPmNhvmpX9VcgKuwHEsAGJ~qj~RHDnDOrQoDm~aWdf3sdlgt4eoVAUmuIH7I8gy2WE8H1m3MKIDjfN8gR4pg2nGL~jIK759Z3ok8vztnAHCt8VCLfWCx~bCiKGimToUqYi9CoHJuv0VDx15GTxRCyndY7XSvgxXfF9KoUrjgCOA~rVEGzTl4n5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763423&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two examples of extended Lyman\u2009\u03b1 arcs found in the A370 MUSE mosaic: the merging pair System 24 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.9160; cyan contours) and the giant arc System 29 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.4897; green contours). In both cases the narrow-band Lyman\u2009\u03b1 flux is significantly larger than the observed continuum counterpart, highlighted by the magenta ellipses.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=WWMJERoV50LXiQFUUe2XJfjKaqog3Egma97gk1A8f5VOO4Rt3JxaGaOWXuysr4SPNULfmhK3p2qU6peYQJoaF5jYmqM07xTm0eIDEAN4k9-wmlV5omeVexC4ylFbpZ8EQXj~~h0eNa1Nf1i1RD904e54Ij4LoKfWBpNngK7BI6JrAzR0JcTOKSVGKj99CUnebw8Y5~WP1JLPTOUtUrlJuF714xs3gGC4toroDi3opy68gLSA~hmpDsi9GHe-LWhakh2TiWGmkc4guKYKFSh89muzlPA8UHnOCn~3IgSQMJ75oRdwETOYZiUtdChY~grb48QQ9M7Cy9ea3mSB1cHEMg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two examples of extended Lyman\u2009\u03b1 arcs found in the A370 MUSE mosaic: the merging pair System 24 (z\u00a0= 4.9160; cyan contours) and the giant arc System 29 (z\u00a0= 4.4897; green contours). In both cases the narrow-band Lyman\u2009\u03b1 flux is significantly larger than the observed continuum counterpart, highlighted by the magenta ellipses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763423/stz620fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=AAoaTZ~TnTPM485u5G2uKWT0F5hjrW5dxji8Ay~Trw~iKxergCleN~vvEoza1-xn2vgd9VlA014-V-B~QBU7Al72fOQGgBOZUk6W~jj6~7kO-5cHygWwH9Oj49DDwgxkeMW4EyONR3pF2J76XiJ79AUHXCd5OWWwPmNhvmpX9VcgKuwHEsAGJ~qj~RHDnDOrQoDm~aWdf3sdlgt4eoVAUmuIH7I8gy2WE8H1m3MKIDjfN8gR4pg2nGL~jIK759Z3ok8vztnAHCt8VCLfWCx~bCiKGimToUqYi9CoHJuv0VDx15GTxRCyndY7XSvgxXfF9KoUrjgCOA~rVEGzTl4n5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763423&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two examples of extended Lyman\u2009\u03b1 arcs found in the A370 MUSE mosaic: the merging pair System 24 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.9160; cyan contours) and the giant arc System 29 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.4897; green contours). In both cases the narrow-band Lyman\u2009\u03b1 flux is significantly larger than the observed continuum counterpart, highlighted by the magenta ellipses.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the 18 systems, 3 are independently presented in other works: <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> identify System 24 (labelled system 20 in that paper), while <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> detect System 26 (labelled system 47) and System 29 (split into two systems, 34 and 35). These studies also partially identify five other systems, but without additional spectroscopic information they miss (or misidentify) counterimages that we detect in MUSE. These are summarized as follows. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 25 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 16): Images 25.1 (D16.2) and 25.2 (D16.1) are identified though slightly offset from the bright Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission, while Image 25.3 is missed. Though it lies in the central part of the cluster, this image is significantly fainter than the others in MUSE, and does not have an obvious <em>HST</em> counterpart. Its long extended Lyman\u2009\u03b1 halo and matching spectral line profile, along with its prediction in the GTO model, make us confident it is a real counterimage.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 27 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 27): Images 27.1 (D27.2) and 27.3 (D27.1) are identified. The third image in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> (D27.3) is a misidentified object at a different redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.2754). The correct counterimage (Image 27.2) is slightly farther south-west than the candidate presented in that work and is significantly fainter.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 28 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 21): Images 28.1 (D21.1) and 28.2 (D21.2) are identified. Image 28.3, a faint companion at the far-eastern side of the cluster, is missed.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 38 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 30): Image 38.1 (D30.1) is correctly identified, while Image 38.2 (D30.2) is missed. However, this may simply be a transcription error as the coordinates of D30.2 point to a patch of blank sky, and the published declinations of D30.1 and D30.2 are identical.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">System 40 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> system 42): <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> identify the three southern images in this system \u2013 Images 40.2, 40.3, and 40.4 (K42.1, K42.2, and K42.3, respectively) \u2013 but miss the northernmost Image 40.1, which lies very close to the northern brightest cluster galaxy (BCG). Though heavily contaminated by the BCG, we still see faint traces of Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission in narrow-band MUSE imaging.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To be as complete as possible, we do attempt to measure redshifts from all other multiple-image candidates presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a>, though we are largely unable to do so: Many of these systems are quite faint, and their extracted spectra contain only noise. At the same time, much like Systems 8 and 11, many have photometric redshift estimates that are not optimal for a MUSE detection. One major exception is <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 15, a bright spiral galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.0315 being galaxy\u2013galaxy lensed by a single cluster member in the north-west corner. Conversely, we are able to reject <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> system 24 as being not multiply imaged but rather a chance alignment of three faint cluster members (D24.1, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3788; D24.2, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3721; D24.3, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3749). We also measure a tentative redshift for <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> image D14.1 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.2777) based on a faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] line, though it is at low confidence and we do not see this line in the two counterimages D14.2 and D14.3 (located in the shallower outskirts of the mosaic.) Without a strong confirmation, we do not use this redshift during the lens-modelling process (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>), opting instead to fit the system\u2019s redshift as a free parameter. We note, however, that the best-fitting redshift in our final model (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.272\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016) is remarkably close to the tentative spectroscopic value.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following discussions held during the HFF Public Modeling Challenge, a collaborative project bringing together several lens-modelling teams to work with common data sets as a way to better characterize systematic differences between modelling techniques,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> we include D14 and D15 as constraints to the model (as Systems 41 and 42, respectively), along with three others (Systems 43 to 45) without any redshift measurement. We will discuss this selection more in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a>. All constraints (with or without a measured redshift) are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and their spatial distribution in A370 is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The redshift distribution of spectroscopic multiple images can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132763427\" scrollto-destination=\"132763427\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=zUr9qDe~fIJ~f5LDCumoh-dxWXosaNcbIGmdzn85hH57b8s5-X8GsIHzN3eIwajJMjAFeHV-iSyeOlW1LaI5eurQ4sdYLie~8lGeuYmKsrwVYiFbsx2eGDW8K0x357hv5iF5iwepEiQPnI4RAW6cWBnNztA~q0ShO1~Q9J5J2qaLjB59vn3UDY~esM6~syi4l4HMYGX2tC8IA7r-LoRH4X~uSFjYHUerpuxnEhRk4Loq3uj5I~p0mixBQi136L75GRG3DEDdLNkTt-wUm-k-H-~GnFDqcuymGjy69bI8BBFdFEZVud86vy0Qv-8hGJ8nSIRorXBmUudoFdyj9co8ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift histogram of multiply imaged galaxies in the A370 field. Solid-colour bars represent individual systems, while the hashed bars include all counterimages that make up these systems. The colour scheme here mimics the redshift ranges used in Fig.\u00a03.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763427/stz620fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763427\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=3W-Pn-G0cQd0rCO4x1cMjdFCpGnp1eQpZC3CwoEbZVDbjoCR3cqCdsoBDcCSjLTbT3RmqUI5XIz~0PNUh2qlfVbytA26i0rdG2ufl6vq42qbuXME6~1LdtL-hLG5uZj5mqr~rNJXd4a2Vjw4MsqVBESeQ5N4NgEVoCsrnkRlPzSU5-WJoKbguYOQ4iZBUmiOuJit6fsDpkOF7K6kFjPA-9jbczU6m3H6PaAjh44dVOMiG~36NNCWdT9~4FU4wRxprb6BogSCtfuYPK53fACt~~mBxR64E2rfROHjyS7mBIRiGsnqKfToiP6tGVl5aZwv0nzvxFYuDEWZ~90smw-Crg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763427&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift histogram of multiply imaged galaxies in the A370 field. The colour scheme here mimics the redshift ranges used in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=zUr9qDe~fIJ~f5LDCumoh-dxWXosaNcbIGmdzn85hH57b8s5-X8GsIHzN3eIwajJMjAFeHV-iSyeOlW1LaI5eurQ4sdYLie~8lGeuYmKsrwVYiFbsx2eGDW8K0x357hv5iF5iwepEiQPnI4RAW6cWBnNztA~q0ShO1~Q9J5J2qaLjB59vn3UDY~esM6~syi4l4HMYGX2tC8IA7r-LoRH4X~uSFjYHUerpuxnEhRk4Loq3uj5I~p0mixBQi136L75GRG3DEDdLNkTt-wUm-k-H-~GnFDqcuymGjy69bI8BBFdFEZVud86vy0Qv-8hGJ8nSIRorXBmUudoFdyj9co8ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift histogram of multiply imaged galaxies in the A370 field. The colour scheme here mimics the redshift ranges used in Fig.\u00a03.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763427/stz620fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763427\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=3W-Pn-G0cQd0rCO4x1cMjdFCpGnp1eQpZC3CwoEbZVDbjoCR3cqCdsoBDcCSjLTbT3RmqUI5XIz~0PNUh2qlfVbytA26i0rdG2ufl6vq42qbuXME6~1LdtL-hLG5uZj5mqr~rNJXd4a2Vjw4MsqVBESeQ5N4NgEVoCsrnkRlPzSU5-WJoKbguYOQ4iZBUmiOuJit6fsDpkOF7K6kFjPA-9jbczU6m3H6PaAjh44dVOMiG~36NNCWdT9~4FU4wRxprb6BogSCtfuYPK53fACt~~mBxR64E2rfROHjyS7mBIRiGsnqKfToiP6tGVl5aZwv0nzvxFYuDEWZ~90smw-Crg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763427&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift histogram of multiply imaged galaxies in the A370 field. class=\"chapter-para\">Multiply imaged systems.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf12\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf12\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em>Unless otherwise specified (i.e. a measurement having fewer than four significant digits), spectroscopic redshifts have an uncertainty \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0= \u00b10.0001. Redshifts enclosed in braces are not spectroscopic, instead fitted by the model as free parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf13\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf13\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Objects are classified according to the FF Public Modeling Challenge convention (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a>.) <em>Gold</em> systems are considered the most reliable constraints, while <em>copper</em> systems are the most uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf14\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf14\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">*These systems are not used as constraints in our mass model. Our best-fitting solution merges Image 10.1 and 10.2 into a single constraint, while Image 16.2 is predicted but is not seen in either MUSE or <em>HST</em> data (see details in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf15\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf15\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">**While originally identified as unique systems, updated modelling suggests they are in fact counterimages of other objects (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec td></tr><tr><td>31.1\u00a0</td><td>39.9747496\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5693301\u00a0</td><td>5.4476\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>31.2\u00a0</td><td>39.980667\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5747346\u00a0</td><td>5.4476\u00a0</td><td>bronze\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>31.3\u00a0</td><td>39.956156\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5786786\u00a0</td><td>5.4476\u00a0</td><td>bronze\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>32.1\u00a0</td><td>39.9662845\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5693446\u00a0</td><td>4.4953\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>32.2\u00a0</td><td>39.988097\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5751871\u00a0</td><td>4.4953\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>32.3\u00a0</td><td>39.960682\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5783795\u00a0</td><td>4.4953\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>33.1\u00a0</td><td>39.9627222\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5860036\u00a0</td><td>4.882\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>33.2\u00a0</td><td>39.9662152\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5879961\u00a0</td><td>4.882\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>34.1\u00a0</td><td>39.9701070\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5701499\u00a0</td><td>5.2437\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>34.2\u00a0</td><td>39.971805\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5880395\u00a0</td><td>5.2437\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>34.3\u00a0</td><td>39.9585664\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5817008\u00a0</td><td>5.2437\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>34.4\u00a0</td><td>39.985048\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.579559\u00a0</td><td>5.2437\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>35.1\u00a0</td><td>39.981538\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5658624\u00a0</td><td>6.1735\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>35.2\u00a0</td><td>39.9758248\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5644423\u00a0</td><td>6.1735\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>36.1\u00a0</td><td>39.9624435\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5807098\u00a0</td><td>6.2855\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>36.2\u00a0</td><td>39.965996\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5843845\u00a0</td><td>6.2855\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>37.1**\u00a0</td><td>39.9703912\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5687943\u00a0</td><td>5.6489\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>37.2**\u00a0</td><td>39.970428\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5694203\u00a0</td><td>5.6489\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>38.1\u00a0</td><td>39.977154\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5737917\u00a0</td><td>3.20\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>38.2\u00a0</td><td>39.975063\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5721045\u00a0</td><td>3.20\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>39.1\u00a0</td><td>39.970546\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5693801\u00a0</td><td>4.9441\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>39.2\u00a0</td><td>39.969977\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5700367\u00a0</td><td>4.9441\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>39.3\u00a0</td><td>39.985223\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5793885\u00a0</td><td>4.9441\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>39.4\u00a0</td><td>39.971395\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5880200\u00a0</td><td>4.9441\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>40.1\u00a0</td><td>39.970632\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5710393\u00a0</td><td>4.3381\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>40.2\u00a0</td><td>39.983162\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5796664\u00a0</td><td>4.3381\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>40.3\u00a0</td><td>39.973383\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5874465\u00a0</td><td>4.3381\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>40.4\u00a0</td><td>39.957967\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5815081\u00a0</td><td>4.3381\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>41.1\u00a0</td><td>39.965442\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5780222\u00a0</td><td>{1.272\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016}\u00a0</td><td>silver\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>41.2\u00a0</td><td>39.967933\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5773472\u00a0</td><td>{1.272\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016}\u00a0</td><td>silver\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>41.3\u00a0</td><td>39.982296\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5769750\u00a0</td><td>{1.272\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.016}\u00a0</td><td>silver\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>42.1\u00a0</td><td>39.963579\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5656333\u00a0</td><td>1.0315\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>42.2\u00a0</td><td>39.962958\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5661111\u00a0</td><td>1.0315\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>42.3\u00a0</td><td>39.963375\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5659528\u00a0</td><td>1.0315\u00a0</td><td>gold\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>43.1\u00a0</td><td>39.962117\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5752500\u00a0</td><td>{1.973\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.034}\u00a0</td><td>bronze\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>43.2\u00a0</td><td>39.984054\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5733556\u00a0</td><td>{1.973\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.034}\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>43.3\u00a0</td><td>39.966563\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5696694\u00a0</td><td>{1.973\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.034}\u00a0</td><td>bronze\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>44.1\u00a0</td><td>39.977717\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5827917\u00a0</td><td>{2.336\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027}\u00a0</td><td>silver\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>44.2\u00a0</td><td>39.976646\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5836028\u00a0</td><td>{2.336\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.027}\u00a0</td><td>silver\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>45.1\u00a0</td><td>39.982400\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5811000\u00a0</td><td>{8.593\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.432}\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>45.2\u00a0</td><td>39.975875\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.5872600\u00a0</td><td>{8.593\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.432}\u00a0</td><td>copper\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf12\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf12\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em>Unless otherwise specified (i.e. a measurement having fewer than four significant digits), spectroscopic redshifts have an uncertainty \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0= \u00b10.0001. Redshifts enclosed in braces are not spectroscopic, instead fitted by the model as free parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf13\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf13\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Objects are classified according to the FF Public Modeling Challenge convention (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a>.) <em>Gold</em> systems are considered the most reliable constraints, while <em>copper</em> systems are the most uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf14\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf14\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">*These systems are not used as constraints in our mass model. Our best-fitting solution merges Image 10.1 and 10.2 into a single constraint, while Image 16.2 is predicted but is not seen in either MUSE or <em>HST</em> data (see details in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf15\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf15\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">**While originally identified as unique systems, updated modelling suggests they are in fact counterimages of other objects (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.4</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132763428\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763429 id=\"132763429\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-2>3.3.2 Cluster members</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster members represent another significant component of the spectroscopic catalogue, and as in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> they make up the majority of redshifts measured in the field. With a larger sample of cluster members, we can better characterize small-scale mass components in the A370 lens model, giving us a more complete picture of the total mass distribution. At the same time, an accurate representation of the (3D) positions of these galaxies provides information about the internal structure and dynamics of the cluster itself.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To identify these galaxies from the catalogue directly, we simply select all objects with a redshift close to the A370 systemic value (<em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 0.375) and treat these systems as cluster members. Although we do not initially apply a hard limit to this selection, we find that the range from <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.35 to <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.4 is considerably overdense compared to the rest of the catalogue, and the redshift distribution of galaxies within this range are well fitted by a Gaussian with \u03bc\u00a0= 0.3745 and \u03c3\u00a0= 0.0077, corresponding to a physical velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>V</em></sub>\u00a0= 1680\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is consistent with a massive lensing cluster. We therefore take the 0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4 limits to be the A370 cluster boundary, which is only slightly larger than a 3\u03c3 spread about the Gaussian mean. This matches the redshift parameter space we use in the GTO catalogue, and we note that a Gaussian redshift distribution is expected for a system that is gravitationally bound and dynamically relaxed (e.g. Wen\u00a0&amp; Han <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) \u2013 though any deviation from a pure Gaussian can be a sign of substructure (e.g. Girardi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). While we could in principle apply a radial cut-off to the selection criteria as well, the new MUSE mosaic is well within the virial radius of the cluster (<em>r</em><sub>vir</sub> \u223c 1\u2009Mpc, corresponding to \u223c195\u2009arcsec at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.375), so an assumption that all objects are cluster members is not especially unwarranted. Applying these limits, we find a total of 244 cluster objects, representing a four-fold increase from the GTO catalogue.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We easily identify the two BCGs in the catalogue, and note that each has a different redshift, with the northern galaxy (catalogue ID 11917; <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3780) slightly redder than <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub> and the southern galaxy (ID 8844; <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3733) slightly bluer. However, unlike other merging clusters with significant MUSE coverage, such as Abell 2744 (Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and MACSJ0416 (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>; Richard et\u00a0al., in preparation), we do not see distinct subpopulations of cluster redshifts centred around each BCG. Instead, the single-peaked Gaussian used to initially identify the cluster is a good fit to the entire population. This may imply that the merger is occurring nearly face-on, or \u2013 given the elongated X-ray contours (see e.g. Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>) and similarly shaped centralized mass distribution (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a>) \u2013 that the merging components have already passed through each other once, allowing the two populations to mix.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Aside from the BCGs, we also investigate the bright northern \u2018crown\u2019 of galaxies presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>, finding that (as we expect) all have redshifts consistent with being cluster members. Projecting these galaxies into 3D space, we find that they are not tightly grouped together but instead circle around the outskirts of the cluster, approximately creating a ring above the BCGs. While this would suggest that the crown galaxies are not strictly associated with each other and instead a 2D projection of several galaxies falling towards the central potential, we do not include peculiar velocity effects in our projections, which can create additional separation in redshift space. We note, however, that the three bright galaxies in the easternmost section of the crown do appear close together and have a small velocity separation (\u0394<em>V</em> \u223c 325\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>). This coincides with the location of the \u2018crown clump\u2019 of the GTO model, providing additional physical motivation for this mass component.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the majority of cluster members have only absorption features in their spectra and appear as passive early-type galaxies in <em>HST</em> imaging, nearly 40 show [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] or H\u2009\u03b1 emission (or both). Most emission-line objects appear near the outskirts of the cluster and have redshifts close to the low or high end of the redshift distribution, suggesting that they are infalling or otherwise interacting with the ICM. The most prominent examples of this are four jellyfish galaxies that show evidence of extreme tidal stripping and have prominent \u2018tails\u2019 of shocked gas in the MUSE cube. Three of these galaxies (IDs 15715, 12808, and 16798) are located in the north of the cluster, near the crown. The fourth (object 8006) is further to the south and positioned eastwards of the southern BCG. We explicitly mention this object (particularly its tail of shocked gas), as it helps to resolve a peculiar observation seen in the GTO cube. Specifically, in our previous paper we discussed the unusual cluster member CL49, an object with a divergent velocity field and no <em>HST</em> counterpart. Thanks to the larger mosaic data, we now see that this emission is simply the bottom section of the jellyfish gas stream (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"132763435\" scrollto-destination=\"132763435\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=1lnE~Sg4HpK1l5iNlAsO8pMAh8b3kADUaiTx1uZkyAb5mc0FlTm0UErXvNR2nBaUbP0YliWbpc33Y8-k4mUpY3XNx9gWtdgeIKr0v3d04fgH9cIbMInihQC-BuVeR9rDoUTwKiQmcZYgxcW~Op~LZAbg2ycCy~439X2EZpt~pt3ZS8xdTpQlCLR8dq279rk3m1BjjWmX7Z9OgkLinGP5TnxrwMFE0hSWbkmSRlkv9A1qwelUtxSXl1g3In1pFsX7L7uiAG7D0pjD2MvwwTccMkVCA8qIR3w7qvRuiKAYKRCTROSoDZ4k8njRqY8r9Ok8utuZxfAhrk3xKEljyOgmDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"[$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$] emission associated with the unusual object CL49 from L17 (cyan contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5157\u2009\u00c5) and a nearby jellyfish galaxy (ID 8006; red contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5167\u2009\u00c5). Stepping through the MUSE cube we find that the emission flows seamlessly from the cyan contours to the red, suggesting that the two contour regions are part of the same \u2018tail\u2019 flowing out of the jellyfish galaxy at an offset velocity \u0394V \u223c 420\u2009km\u2009s\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763435/stz620fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763435\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=RSY1ctXoPeiYTdC3RJ7R0ca5RVK4VxXn~MmMbqv~bnZq-aK3n09fUe1ZYPhDbfQ~w75C3UGxy--sGi8t1swN2jkrnSQMS5Cx8YMH5eHzk-HQhn7Ur6GDh1xITs1449TWATaXRcfH9d9dSgVJPlsgERHCKcKeFv65mLZTdelg1zh8lwLeuGI8J7hOKfHjimS8rGXaVCCBru4oNOQwGMZtc1HV6enDGMqzVhsFqr5SnbONGHdyxwBG5KtIncin16kbSCLpPxsz4~-lBTlq~jMLf6LsAhu0Le4ytzDg9oNk34Chjb7rWQ-6DD9yCDM6cXCJaAZjFYlaKCTXRV-Ts84xtQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763435&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission associated with the unusual object CL49 from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> (cyan contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5157\u2009\u00c5) and a nearby jellyfish galaxy (ID 8006; red contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5167\u2009\u00c5). Stepping through the MUSE cube we find that the emission flows seamlessly from the cyan contours to the red, suggesting that the two contour regions are part of the same \u2018tail\u2019 flowing out of the jellyfish galaxy at an offset velocity \u0394<em>V</em> \u223c 420\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=1lnE~Sg4HpK1l5iNlAsO8pMAh8b3kADUaiTx1uZkyAb5mc0FlTm0UErXvNR2nBaUbP0YliWbpc33Y8-k4mUpY3XNx9gWtdgeIKr0v3d04fgH9cIbMInihQC-BuVeR9rDoUTwKiQmcZYgxcW~Op~LZAbg2ycCy~439X2EZpt~pt3ZS8xdTpQlCLR8dq279rk3m1BjjWmX7Z9OgkLinGP5TnxrwMFE0hSWbkmSRlkv9A1qwelUtxSXl1g3In1pFsX7L7uiAG7D0pjD2MvwwTccMkVCA8qIR3w7qvRuiKAYKRCTROSoDZ4k8njRqY8r9Ok8utuZxfAhrk3xKEljyOgmDA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"[$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$] emission associated with the unusual object CL49 from L17 (cyan contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5157\u2009\u00c5) and a nearby jellyfish galaxy (ID 8006; red contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5167\u2009\u00c5). Stepping through the MUSE cube we find that the emission flows seamlessly from the cyan contours to the red, suggesting that the two contour regions are part of the same \u2018tail\u2019 flowing out of the jellyfish galaxy at an offset velocity \u0394V \u223c 420\u2009km\u2009s\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763435/stz620fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763435\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=RSY1ctXoPeiYTdC3RJ7R0ca5RVK4VxXn~MmMbqv~bnZq-aK3n09fUe1ZYPhDbfQ~w75C3UGxy--sGi8t1swN2jkrnSQMS5Cx8YMH5eHzk-HQhn7Ur6GDh1xITs1449TWATaXRcfH9d9dSgVJPlsgERHCKcKeFv65mLZTdelg1zh8lwLeuGI8J7hOKfHjimS8rGXaVCCBru4oNOQwGMZtc1HV6enDGMqzVhsFqr5SnbONGHdyxwBG5KtIncin16kbSCLpPxsz4~-lBTlq~jMLf6LsAhu0Le4ytzDg9oNk34Chjb7rWQ-6DD9yCDM6cXCJaAZjFYlaKCTXRV-Ts84xtQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763435&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission associated with the unusual object CL49 from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> (cyan contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5157\u2009\u00c5) and a nearby jellyfish galaxy (ID 8006; red contours; \u03bb\u00a0= 5167\u2009\u00c5). Stepping through the MUSE cube we find that the emission flows seamlessly from the cyan contours to the red, suggesting that the two contour regions are part of the same \u2018tail\u2019 flowing out of the jellyfish galaxy at an offset velocity \u0394<em>V</em> \u223c 420\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763436 id=\"132763436\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3-3>3.3.3 Foreground and background objects</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The final subset of the redshift catalogue contains all remaining objects: stars, foreground galaxies, and non-multiply imaged background galaxies. These help to fill in the line-of-sight picture of A370, and (in some cases) also provide information about the lens model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify 11 stars in the field, including the very bright star (ID 10011) south-west of the cluster at the extreme edge of the MUSE footprint. Moving outside of the Milky Way, we detect 57 galaxies in front of A370, with redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.1 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.35. A large fraction of these objects are late-type galaxies with blue colours and prominent H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission, though six show only absorption features in their spectra and have more elliptical morphologies. While the foreground systems do not display any obvious spatial clustering in the HFF data \u2013 galaxies are more or less evenly distributed throughout the mosaic footprint \u2013 we do find slight spectral overdensities at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.26 and <em>z</em> \u223c 0.32, which could indicate the presence of coincident galaxy groups. Given their relative paucity, it is unlikely that these candidate groups will significantly affect the overall mass model, but we investigate this more thoroughly in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are considerably more background galaxies in the catalogue, especially in the range from just behind the cluster to the start of the MUSE redshift desert. In particular, we identify 134 (singly imaged) galaxies between <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.4 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.5, which, like their foreground counterparts, largely appear blue and pink in optical (ACS) colour and show prominent emission lines \u2013 though we do find eight purely passive early-type galaxies randomly spread throughout the mosaic. The observed emission lines are predominantly [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>], as H\u2009\u03b1 redshifts out of MUSE spectra at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.425. While some objects appear to be well-defined late-type galaxies, a larger fraction have clumpy, irregular morphologies, suggesting that many of these systems are actively forming stars. One interesting example is Object 15491, located in the far north of the mosaic. This galaxy has a strong blue power-law continuum, and several emission features with extremely high equivalent widths, including a strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{Mg\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>[\u03bb2797, 2804] doublet. While weak extended emission can be seen in the HFF imaging, it has a bright point-like centre suggesting the object is an AGN.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As in the foreground, galaxies in this redshift range are evenly spread throughout the mosaic and largely have a flat redshift distribution. However, we do find one prominent redshift overdensity at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.05, where the number of objects is more than double any other redshift bin. This overdensity, which is also detected in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>, consists of a significantly larger number of galaxies than either of the foreground groups and may be indicative of additional substructure. As background objects, these galaxies also have a much better chance of affecting the positions of observed lensing constraints, so we investigate their effects on the mass model in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Within the redshift desert, we find two objects (ID 10793, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.3830; ID 13028, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.8050) with moderate <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emission in the north-east and north-west of the cluster, respectively, above the crown. We also identify a strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emitter in the south-west of the cluster (ID 4139, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.9655) with a bright UV continuum and several other emission and absorption features, including <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{Fe\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>* [\u03bb \u223c 2400\u2009\u00c5, \u03bb \u223c 2600\u2009\u00c5] emission, which is useful for probing galactic winds (see e.g. Finley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Additionally, we identify a fourth potential <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{C\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] emitter (ID 11481, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.5607) in the north-east, and three objects with weak UV absorption features (ID 6655, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.1240; ID 13600, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.5442; and ID 14822, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2.8897) at the western edges of the mosaic, but we stress that these identifications are made at low confidence (<em>C</em> \u00a0=\u00a01) and could simply be noise.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we detect 14 singly imaged galaxies in the catalogue at distances beyond the redshift desert (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z \\gtrsim 3$|\u2060</span>). Given the high redshifts of these objects, they are largely located in the outskirts of the mosaic, outside of the A370 multiple-image zone. In nearly all cases, galaxies are identified by strong Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission, though we do detect two Lyman-break systems with several other prominent UV-continuum absorption features (ID 12137, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.2510; ID 14650, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 4.2561) in the northern region of the cluster. With the exception of the very lowest redshift galaxies (<em>z</em> \u223c 2.9) and the Lyman-break objects, most systems are barely resolved in the HFF imaging with limited morphological information. Likewise, the extracted spectra often show little to no continuum emission, relying solely on the Lyman\u2009\u03b1 feature for redshift identification. The typical line flux for the Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission is 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221218</sup>\u2009erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, which, when coupled by the relatively low magnification values (\u03bc \u223c 2.3) associated with these sources, indicates that the lines are intrinsically bright, especially when compared to their multiply imaged counterparts at similar redshifts.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763443 id=\"132763443\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763444 id=\"132763444\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Method</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To model the total cluster mass, we use the publicly available software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo\u00a0&amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Based on a \u2018parametric\u2019 approach, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> constructs an overall distribution using a series of individual components, each with an analytic profile. This is in contrast to \u2018non-parametric\u2019 methods such as <span class=\"small-caps\">wslap</span>\u00a0+\u00a0(Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), which utilize a free-form grid of pixels without regard to a particular shape. The specific processes we employ in this work mirror those used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>, and a complete description of the procedure can be found there. However, to aid the reader we briefly describe the general technique here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit the system with a set of elliptical mass potentials, including both large cluster-scale haloes and smaller galaxy-scale masses. Each potential is constructed with a dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical profile (dPIE; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), a distribution that matches empirical cluster data well and has enough flexibility to model variations at all scales. The basic dPIE halo is described by seven parameters, including position (\u03b1 and \u03b4), position angle (\u03b8), ellipticity (\u03f5), central velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>0</sub>), and two scale radii (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>) that modify the inner and outer mass slopes of the profile, respectively. To optimize a given model, we take known multiple-image systems (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>) as constraints, minimizing the rms distance between the model-predicted locations of these objects and their actual positions on the sky. <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> generates a model prediction by first transforming constraints from the lens plane (observed positions) to the source plane (intrinsic, undeflected positions), grouping all counterimages of a given system together, and then calculating the barycentre coordinates of each group. These barycentre positions are then transformed back to the lens plane, where they can be compared to the original observations. Throughout this process, the code continually updates and tests new parameter configurations, using a Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling routine to search for the maximum likelihood region of parameter space. Once this region is discovered, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> probes the area using a fixed number of MCMC realizations, treating the most probable configuration as the best-fitting model and averaging the others to determine parameter uncertainties. The exact number of sample iterations is specified by the user, which in this work we set to 100.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">During model optimization, we allow all parameters of the cluster-scale potentials to vary freely, with the exception of <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>, which we fix at 800\u2009kpc (155\u2009arcsec) since the mosaic data still do not extend far enough to put a meaningful constraint on its value. Conversely, we fix many of the parameters of the galaxy-scale haloes, since these components represent individual cluster-member galaxies and their values can be measured from the data directly. In particular, we match the \u03b1, \u03b4, \u03f5, and \u03b8 parameters for each galaxy to their observed values in the HFF <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> image. To further reduce the model parameter space, we do not fit the remaining galaxy-scale parameters independently. Instead, we only model the parameters of a typical <em>L</em>* galaxy, then calibrate all other potentials with an empirical scaling relation, given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\begin{split} \\sigma _{0,\\rm gal} &amp;= \\sigma _0^* \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm gal}}{L^*}\\right)^{1/4},\\\\\r\nr_{\\rm core, gal} &amp;= r_{\\rm core}^* \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm gal}}{L^*}\\right)^{1/2},\\\\\r\nr_{\\rm cut, gal} &amp;= r_{\\rm cut}^* \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm gal}}{L^*}\\right)^{1/2}, \\end{split}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _0^*$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^*$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> are the optimized components of the <em>L</em>* galaxy. We note, however, that we fix the value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^*$|</span> to 15\u2009kpc, as it is difficult to constrain a true core radius for small-scale mass distributions. Additionally, we limit the variation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> to be between 10 and 30\u2009kpc, in order to account for the effects of tidal stripping within the cluster (e.g. Halkola, Seitz\u00a0&amp; Pannella <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), and because there is often a strong degeneracy between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _0^*$|\u2060</span>. For reference, <em>L</em>*\u00a0= 3.19\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10\u2009</sup>L<sub>\u2299</sub> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.375, corresponding to an apparent magnitude <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 19.78.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763448 id=\"132763448\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Model construction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Choosing a robust set of model components (both potentials and multiple-image constraints) is crucial to this work, as it allows us to reproduce the true distribution of A370 as accurately as possible. Since there is no direct evidence to constrain the number of large-scale dark matter haloes in the cluster, we begin by mirroring the GTO model. Namely, we include four such mass components in our initial guess: two located around the BCGs, a third \u2018bridge\u2019 clump connecting the BCG haloes and flattening the central mass profile, and finally the crown clump in the north-east of the cluster. However, after the initial model run, we experiment with different numbers of cluster-scale potentials (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a>) to see if an alternative parametrization is more appropriate.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">When selecting galaxy-scale potentials, we first investigate sources in the catalogue that fall in the cluster redshift range (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4). While we can in principle include all of these galaxies as potentials, doing so would make the model needlessly complex, as faint (i.e. low-mass) cluster members do not significantly contribute to the total mass budget. From past experience we find that applying a nominal magnitude cut-off (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> &lt; 22.6) keeps the model computationally manageable without affecting its accuracy, so we maintain these \u2018bright\u2019 cluster members as model components and disregard the rest. To supplement these galaxies, we apply a colour\u2013colour cut to the entire HFF field in order to select any potential cluster members without a spectroscopic redshift.
