  <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term at-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763377 id=\"132763377\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present an updated strong-lensing analysis of the massive cluster Abell 370 (A370), continuing the work first presented in L17. In this new analysis, we take advantage of the deeper imaging data from the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> Frontier Fields programme, as well as a large spectroscopic mosaic obtained with the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). Thanks to the extended coverage of this mosaic, we probe the full 3D distribution of galaxies in the field, giving us a unique picture of the extended structure of the cluster and its surroundings. Our final catalogue contains 584 redshifts, representing the largest spectroscopic catalogue of A370 to date. Constructing the model, we measure a total mass distribution that is quantitatively similar to our previous work \u2013 though to ensure a low rms error in the model fit, we invoke a significantly large external shear term. Using the redshift catalogue, we search for other bound groups of galaxies, which may give rise to a more physical interpretation of this shear. We identify three structures in narrow redshift ranges along the line of sight, highlighting possible infalling substructures into the main cluster halo. We also discover additional substructure candidates in low-resolution imaging at larger projected radii. More spectroscopic coverage of these regions (pushing close to the A370 virial radius) and more extended, high-resolution imaging will be required to investigate this possibility, further advancing the analysis of these interesting developments.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;large-scale structure of Universe&quot;\">large-scale structure of Universe</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763379 id=\"132763379\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Probing the formation and build-up of matter from large to small scales is a key ingredient in understanding the Universe. With an accurate picture of structure formation, we can gain critical insight into a variety of astrophysical topics, such as galaxy evolution (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Franx et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Wetzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Conselice <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), cosmology (e.g. Percival\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Blake, James\u00a0&amp; Poole <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and even the nature of dark matter itself (e.g. Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bozek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Clusters of galaxies \u2013 gravitationally bound collections of tens to hundreds of individual galaxies \u2013 act as ideal laboratories for this phenomenon, as they provide information about structure formation at several physical scales simultaneously. Forming at the intersections of long filaments of the cosmic web (e.g. Bond, Kofman\u00a0&amp; Pogosyan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Springel, Frenk\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kravtsov\u00a0&amp; Borgani <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), clusters trace the large-scale structure of the Universe, while the accretion of smaller haloes on to the primary mass (either via these filaments or independently) showcases more compact distributions in the so-called non-linear regime of the lambda cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmological model (Bullock\u00a0&amp; Boylan-Kolchin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). At the same time, mergers between two (or more) pre-existing clusters can highlight structure build-up at intermediate scales, and individual mass configurations within and around the cluster lead to localized pockets of substructure, which represents another important aspect of mass accumulation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While there are many ways to study the distribution of mass within clusters, including X-ray gas (e.g. Stanford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Ettori et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Merten et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich effect (e.g. Marrone et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Shirasaki, Nagai\u00a0&amp; Lau <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; L\u00f3pez-Corredoira, Guti\u00e9rrez\u00a0&amp; G\u00e9nova-Santos <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and density maps of cluster light (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Bahcall\u00a0&amp; Kulier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Sebesta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), one of the most robust methods is gravitational lensing. Unlike other techniques, lensing does not rely on kinematic effects and makes no assumptions about the dynamic state of the cluster. Lensing is also achromatic, producing the same signal at all frequencies and making it trivially easy to combine information from multiwavelength data sets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Such multiband imaging is a key feature of the Frontier Fields (FF) programme, a campaign designed to obtain deep <em>Hubble</em> (<em>HST</em>) and <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em> imaging of six massive lensing clusters (Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in order to better observe extremely faint and distant (<em>z</em> &gt; 5) galaxies being magnified by the cluster, pushing the boundaries of the observable Universe. Among these faint objects are hundreds of strongly lensed, multiply imaged background galaxies, which are used to model the mass distributions of these clusters with unprecedented accuracy. Since the release of the FF images, analysis of the data in conjunction with other ancillary products has provided numerous insights into cluster mass (e.g. Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Wang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hoag et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Ogrean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Meneghetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), including confirmation that merging lensing clusters \u2013 often the most efficient gravitational lenses (Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) \u2013 have exceedingly complex mass distributions. Specifically, many studies have shown significant substructure populations within cluster fields (e.g. Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Natarajan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams, Sebesta\u00a0&amp; Liesenborgs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and an elevated number of \u2018jellyfish\u2019 galaxies: gas-rich, infalling spiral galaxies being stripped down by the intracluster medium (ICM; e.g. Ebeling, Stephenson\u00a0&amp; Edge <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; McPartland et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presence of complex substructure points to an evolving dynamical mass state, and has a significant impact on the accuracy of model cluster masses: Failure to account for mass concentrations at large clustercentric radii can bias lens models by up to 20\u00a0per\u2009cent (Acebron et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The FF cluster Abell 2744 is a prime example, where the weak-lensing analysis of Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) revealed several massive subhaloes at the cluster redshift, located at projected radii of 0.5\u20131\u2009Mpc from the strong-lensing core. These substructures strongly influenced past central cluster lens modelling (Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), where the inclusion of these haloes mimicked the effects of a previously important ad hoc \u2018external shear\u2019 term and provided a more physical interpretation of the observations. Results from Abell 2744 and other merging clusters (e.g. Girardi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) highlight the fact that substructures are often located at considerable distance from the cluster core, and can be missed in narrowly targeted imaging and spectroscopic campaigns. This is an important motivator for the Beyond Ultra-deep Frontier Fields And Legacy Observations (BUFFALO) project,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> a new survey designed to expand the <em>HST</em> FF (HFF) imaging data by as much as four times the area of the current pointings. This wider area will improve our ability to trace the overall mass profile and substructure characteristics of the dark and luminous components of the FF clusters to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim } 75{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the cluster virial radius (<em>R</em><sub>vir</sub>), using a combination of both strong- and weak-lensing techniques. This will provide critical insight into each cluster\u2019s central assembly history, which can be compared to theoretical predictions from standard \u039bCDM (Vogelsberger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Schaye et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Schwinn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and alternative models (e.g. Kravtsov\u00a0&amp; Borgani <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Koyama <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the high-resolution <em>HST</em> data sets provided by the HFF and BUFFALO projects are useful, imaging alone is not sufficient for this analysis. Indeed, the only robust way to derive physical values from a detected lensing signal is through a combination of imaging <em>and</em> spectroscopy. Historically, lensing clusters have lacked comprehensive spectroscopic coverage due to the inefficient and often time-consuming observing process utilized by traditional instruments. However, this paradigm is changing. Thanks to the arrival of integral field unit spectrographs (IFUs) such as the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), we can now obtain hundreds of high-quality spectra in a given field with only a few hours of integration (e.g. Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). In particular, the wide (1\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u2009arcmin) field of view and high throughput at optical wavelengths (4800\u20139300\u2009\u00c5) make MUSE an efficient tool for capturing redshifts of cluster galaxies, nearby infalling objects, and distant multiply imaged background systems all at once. At the same time, by studying the redshift distribution of other \u2018interloper\u2019 galaxies in the field, it is possible to detect compact groups of objects in front of or behind the cluster (i.e. line-of-sight substructures) that are not often obvious in imaging. Over the past few years, several lensing studies have taken advantage of MUSE spectroscopy (e.g. Karman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bina et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Patr\u00edcio et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>; Griffiths et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) to great effect.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we study the merging cluster Abell 370 (A370) using a combination of HFF imaging and MUSE spectroscopy. Centred at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.375 (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>), A370 is a highly elongated and efficient lens, with an Einstein radius of 39\u2009arcsec at <em>z</em> \u2248 2, a mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\lt 250 \\, \\rm kpc} = 3.8 \\times 10^{14} \\, \\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }$|</span> (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and an X-ray luminosity <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u00a0= 1.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>45</sup>\u2009erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Morandi, Ettori\u00a0&amp; Moscardini <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). A370 is notable for hosting the first confirmed giant gravitational arc, at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.725 (Hammer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and for having a high magnification area (\u03bc &gt; 5\u201310) roughly twice as large as any other FF cluster (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This project follows up our previous investigation into A370 (Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>), which modelled the total mass distribution with the help of a two-hour MUSE pointing in the very core of the cluster. That analysis revealed a number of interesting properties of the system, including a largely flat central mass profile, boxy-shaped mass contours, and the possible existence of a third large-scale halo in the north-east. However, our conclusions regarding structure at extended radii were limited, due to a lack of spectroscopy beyond the central core. Here we expand the original MUSE data with a 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7 2\u2009arcmin mosaic that covers nearly the entire region where strong-lensing constraints are expected to be found, as well as a large fraction of the deep multiband imaging region of the HFF data set. This allows us to investigate our initial claims more rigorously, and also gives us an opportunity to search directly for substructures or other complex mass distributions. Overall, this provides a more complete picture of the structure of A370 and serves as a pathfinder for other upcoming programmes with <em>HST</em> (e.g. BUFFALO) and the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> (<em>JWST</em>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows: In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a> we describe the data used in our analysis and briefly discuss the reduction techniques. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> we explain our spectral extraction process and present an updated catalogue of redshifts in the A370 field. We use these redshifts to generate an initial set of mass models, which we present in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. Next, we identify possible substructure candidates in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a> and modify our models to include the effects of the additional mass. We also discuss our results in this section, paying special attention to the physical interpretation of external shear. Finally, we briefly conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>. Throughout this work, we assume a standard cosmological model of \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0= 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0= 0.7, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. In this framework, a span of 1 arcsec corresponds to a physical distance of 5.162\u2009kpc at the cluster redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.375. Finally, unless otherwise stated all magnitudes are measured using the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763388 id=\"132763388\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To improve our understanding of the cluster we use a combination of imaging and spectroscopic data in this work, both to construct a model of the A370 mass distribution and to identify overdensities in the redshift distribution, which can be indicative of line-of-sight substructure.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763390 id=\"132763390\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>HST</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>, we again use the publicly available HFF image stacks of A370<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> to identify cluster members and multiple-image candidates, and as a basis for spectral extraction in MUSE data (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>). The complete HFF data set covers seven broad-band filters (<em>F</em>435<em>W, F</em>606<em>W, F</em>814<em>W, F</em>105<em>W, F</em>125<em>W, F</em>140<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em>), forming the deepest optical and near-infrared (IR) imaging ever taken of A370. For the three optical bands we use the final Epoch 1 v1.0 stacks (consisting of 20, 10, and 52 <em>HST</em> orbits, respectively), while for the near-IR bands we use the Epoch 2 v1.0 stacks (consisting of 25, 12, 13, and 28 <em>HST</em> orbits), which were not available in our previous work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The addition of deeper near-IR data is especially useful for identifying high-redshift dropout candidates that can be lensed more efficiently by the cluster. Multiband photometry also enhances our analysis by providing important colour information about each object. In particular, we use an optical colour\u2013colour selection criterion to identify cluster members that otherwise lack secure spectroscopic redshifts (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a>), which allows us to build a more complete and robust lens model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To better resolve small, point-source-like objects in the field, we use the images with 30\u2009mas resolution, and to ensure the best possible data quality we use the \u2018selfcal\u2019 charge transfer inefficiency (CTI)-corrected data for the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) images and the \u2018bkgdcor\u2019 data for Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3), which applies corrections for persistence effects and detector artefacts, as well as an improved handling of time-variable sky emission. The full details of the data reduction and cleaning are described in the HFF data archive for A370<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> and in Lotz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763394 id=\"132763394\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For spectroscopic information we turn to MUSE, observing the A370 field using a large mosaic covering \u223c4\u2009arcmin<sup>2</sup>. This mosaic, programme 096.A-0710(A) (PI: Bauer), is an expansion of an initial guaranteed time observing (GTO) programme 094.A-0115(A) (PI: Richard) that focused on the central cluster core. This full mosaic covers a 2\u2009arcmin\u00a0\u00d7 2\u2009arcmin area centred on the cluster, providing nearly complete coverage of the \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019: the area where multiple images of all background galaxies out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 10) are expected to fall (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"132763396\" scrollto-destination=\"132763396\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=t7QjZ~gQCB7bt6Y2xbHPPsGZZQ7goSPtg08ptTY5HQzw4tsvtx4EZAK-x5A9QLeOjum5X2yIrWG0ma-VnLn5PRi1zQo3ou4xnC0a5MNBCdEJgMTjkWxvBgIHbJs7B82ZkK1sRVQFMob9Er9Q4Ke3liiEdmdh53sYHXTwDUfbFj3luXZnYxCB7q7iBDwKj8RqvKNJgpHbuoYi-wObvLNGxUKvZorXx6hu4uW1qF5fbl31yDCVPOXP9DStJzY~QiIsQj211YSuBfpd4Pz0nTDbLcXY137DZpzu0l2mbjrwiogMitmHc9UM7ykNMozNppanLAmIDQzh~JiJoxnUFmV6nQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour image of the A370 field, using the Epoch 1.0 F435W, F606W, and F814W data sets from the Hubble Frontier Fields programme. The region covered by the MUSE mosaic is represented by the thick white line; for reference, we show the original GTO MUSE footprint used in L17 as a dashed white line. In addition, all multiply imaged galaxy constraints used in the lens modelling are shown as coloured circles. The colour of each constraint (gold, silver, bronze, and copper) is based on its ranking according to the HFF public modelling challenge (see Section\u00a04.2 and Table\u00a01 for complete details.) The copper-coloured constraints appear darker than their bronze counterparts. The cyan-coloured circles are items that are predicted but not used in the modelling. The cyan contour traces out the \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019, the region where all multiply imaged objects are expected to fall out to high redshift (z\u00a0= 10).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763396/stz620fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763396\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=UL9ol7dwN1PBAY1FKunGS3ABIMKITiBgsRuw1CpfMu-5fneGJ3G~blQX-eHnBFGILYgVNPKmnvPfFRL7Yum6DWmGbT6~otsk2aDtD0wkaeqdSKIo1U~vJLLZKvlazlTPg6FXM0b7N~rwLSlE0YIZfVcRlwG04s7-MbkLiiIJ3sYMjkw15nRW6yi2UutDEy50x0k4kE-r1Q1RAJWayekWegpXxQPhW3BQTReiV8EsSC7nB3OKZqBAEpvsvPalLJqxOsQdpwJ814QpR6nX36s6sO5uqbogp~eXn5EnJTdgTm5LiYd3BuKXpcrBn9r4ooXN9gISR85qAV4WSXKpZF9cug__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763396&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour image of the A370 field, using the Epoch 1.0 <em>F</em>435<em>W, F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> data sets from the <em>Hubble</em> Frontier Fields programme. The region covered by the MUSE mosaic is represented by the thick white line; for reference, we show the original GTO MUSE footprint used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> as a dashed white line. In addition, all multiply imaged galaxy constraints used in the lens modelling are shown as coloured circles. The colour of each constraint (gold, silver, bronze, and copper) is based on its ranking according to the HFF public modelling challenge (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for complete details.) The copper-coloured constraints appear darker than their bronze counterparts. The cyan-coloured circles are items that are predicted but not used in the modelling. The cyan contour traces out the \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019, the region where all multiply imaged objects are expected to fall out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 10).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=t7QjZ~gQCB7bt6Y2xbHPPsGZZQ7goSPtg08ptTY5HQzw4tsvtx4EZAK-x5A9QLeOjum5X2yIrWG0ma-VnLn5PRi1zQo3ou4xnC0a5MNBCdEJgMTjkWxvBgIHbJs7B82ZkK1sRVQFMob9Er9Q4Ke3liiEdmdh53sYHXTwDUfbFj3luXZnYxCB7q7iBDwKj8RqvKNJgpHbuoYi-wObvLNGxUKvZorXx6hu4uW1qF5fbl31yDCVPOXP9DStJzY~QiIsQj211YSuBfpd4Pz0nTDbLcXY137DZpzu0l2mbjrwiogMitmHc9UM7ykNMozNppanLAmIDQzh~JiJoxnUFmV6nQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour image of the A370 field, using the Epoch 1.0 F435W, F606W, and F814W data sets from the Hubble Frontier Fields programme. The colour of each constraint (gold, silver, bronze, and copper) is based on its ranking according to the HFF public modelling challenge (see Section\u00a04.2 and Table\u00a01 for complete details.) The cyan contour traces out the \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019, the region where all multiply imaged objects are expected to fall out to high redshift (z\u00a0= 10).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763396/stz620fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763396\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=UL9ol7dwN1PBAY1FKunGS3ABIMKITiBgsRuw1CpfMu-5fneGJ3G~blQX-eHnBFGILYgVNPKmnvPfFRL7Yum6DWmGbT6~otsk2aDtD0wkaeqdSKIo1U~vJLLZKvlazlTPg6FXM0b7N~rwLSlE0YIZfVcRlwG04s7-MbkLiiIJ3sYMjkw15nRW6yi2UutDEy50x0k4kE-r1Q1RAJWayekWegpXxQPhW3BQTReiV8EsSC7nB3OKZqBAEpvsvPalLJqxOsQdpwJ814QpR6nX36s6sO5uqbogp~eXn5EnJTdgTm5LiYd3BuKXpcrBn9r4ooXN9gISR85qAV4WSXKpZF9cug__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763396&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour image of the A370 field, using the Epoch 1.0 <em>F</em>435<em>W, F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> data sets from the <em>Hubble</em> Frontier Fields programme. The region covered by the MUSE mosaic is represented by the thick white line; for reference, we show the original GTO MUSE footprint used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> as a dashed white line. In addition, all multiply imaged galaxy constraints used in the lens modelling are shown as coloured circles. The colour of each constraint (gold, silver, bronze, and copper) is based on its ranking according to the HFF public modelling challenge (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for complete details.) The copper-coloured constraints appear darker than their bronze counterparts. The cyan-coloured circles are items that are predicted but not used in the modelling. The cyan contour traces out the \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019, the region where all multiply imaged objects are expected to fall out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 10).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mosaic was designed to have a factor of \u223c3\u20134 higher exposure in the central portion (highest lensing area) of A370 in order to achieve relatively uniform line sensitivity in the face of strong intracluster light, which raises the background for line detection by up to a factor of \u223c2 at the centre. To this end, we obtained 2\u2009h on-source exposure rotated by 28\u00b0 to cover the bulk of the <em>HST</em> WFC \u223c5\u2009arcmin<sup>2</sup> footprint (excluding a bright star), while a further 4\u2009h of on-source exposure was devoted to two pointings centred on the N\u2013S high-magnification region. We incorporated the archival 2\u2009h on-source exposure to deepen the exposure to 8\u2009h in the very centre. In total, the mosaic comprises 18\u2009h of on-source exposure. The full MUSE exposure map can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132763398\" scrollto-destination=\"132763398\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=bUT9VKjE6MhxnowonZ0EBRPgKhyg0tDKxXnSQB2FSLNF~J6h9FwWiFXtpjD4zcF30XauIcxlhj9yohxR76V1Dlp4ZVv4OM28DdTcZati7eFOZixdjd6HO~l9Uy5q6I6oGbySEHKtO~6qNB0vVV0JXTX4oWG12dNGjrr8J3~rA3cn-XcdmuQaDVEAeHt-JiGTFVezRxCZurhN-RaR~o0QrWrPr8T5IRu8J4efrs7TNOza6kvcZSMPTw~pZMhWqVwBKxDL3kAdiT9BcZr-T5Jw3u2M8bZHCWR8MRJK-qJJyh3Gn5dZmR2k0w~WFr~Qlk7qkxrWINa5chguJ3t3Fzq2tA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Exposure-time map of the MUSE mosaic covering A370. The deeper\u2009central region is designed to overcome noise due to strong intracluster light while the outer region covers the remaining section of the cluster core, all with relatively uniform line sensitivity. The thick black line again shows the multiple-image zone and highlights the nearly complete coverage of this area, which greatly improves our ability to spectroscopically detect lens-model constraints (Section\u00a03.3.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763398/stz620fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=dem2yrFk3lEITxC85KxVWGaZzIdZV-JFUZukIXAav9MEhuXhZWpryvpSYtN9adVcgdqcEMQjZ8UHsPXFLxs0ToJSOq8TORDphlVZgbhV1qfh~VmV8MQgHfwYKPtZzk4I3V1UHmJnpYHUxhzedqK78jO1lmuu-fwv4uGma44voJGTTwhOx5FbkEzouKV8WaxvXiU3Dwvvcs7bQ5Kf7J1~vgAh2XTYeDB2QAtxCSEMfjyADglSWunG1r5npKegBuF-GX2zJrlqVBV-zYa424RfYV1ylozq6eJVRcS0XKlExiOhqwfDXomI8YXz6lhmZUyTIlwk~5C-d9KXl0vamuqb2Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763398&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Exposure-time map of the MUSE mosaic covering A370. The deeper\u2009central region is designed to overcome noise due to strong intracluster light while the outer region covers the remaining section of the cluster core, all with relatively uniform line sensitivity. The thick black line again shows the multiple-image zone and highlights the nearly complete coverage of this area, which greatly improves our ability to spectroscopically detect lens-model constraints (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=bUT9VKjE6MhxnowonZ0EBRPgKhyg0tDKxXnSQB2FSLNF~J6h9FwWiFXtpjD4zcF30XauIcxlhj9yohxR76V1Dlp4ZVv4OM28DdTcZati7eFOZixdjd6HO~l9Uy5q6I6oGbySEHKtO~6qNB0vVV0JXTX4oWG12dNGjrr8J3~rA3cn-XcdmuQaDVEAeHt-JiGTFVezRxCZurhN-RaR~o0QrWrPr8T5IRu8J4efrs7TNOza6kvcZSMPTw~pZMhWqVwBKxDL3kAdiT9BcZr-T5Jw3u2M8bZHCWR8MRJK-qJJyh3Gn5dZmR2k0w~WFr~Qlk7qkxrWINa5chguJ3t3Fzq2tA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Exposure-time map of the MUSE mosaic covering A370. The deeper\u2009central region is designed to overcome noise due to strong intracluster light while the outer region covers the remaining section of the cluster core, all with relatively uniform line sensitivity. The thick black line again shows the multiple-image zone and highlights the nearly complete coverage of this area, which greatly improves our ability to spectroscopically detect lens-model constraints (Section\u00a03.3.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763398/stz620fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=dem2yrFk3lEITxC85KxVWGaZzIdZV-JFUZukIXAav9MEhuXhZWpryvpSYtN9adVcgdqcEMQjZ8UHsPXFLxs0ToJSOq8TORDphlVZgbhV1qfh~VmV8MQgHfwYKPtZzk4I3V1UHmJnpYHUxhzedqK78jO1lmuu-fwv4uGma44voJGTTwhOx5FbkEzouKV8WaxvXiU3Dwvvcs7bQ5Kf7J1~vgAh2XTYeDB2QAtxCSEMfjyADglSWunG1r5npKegBuF-GX2zJrlqVBV-zYa424RfYV1ylozq6eJVRcS0XKlExiOhqwfDXomI8YXz6lhmZUyTIlwk~5C-d9KXl0vamuqb2Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763398&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Exposure-time map of the MUSE mosaic covering A370. The deeper\u2009central region is designed to overcome noise due to strong intracluster light while the outer region covers the remaining section of the cluster core, all with relatively uniform line sensitivity. The thick black line again shows the multiple-image zone and highlights the nearly complete coverage of this area, which greatly improves our ability to spectroscopically detect lens-model constraints (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">MUSE was employed in non-AO mode for all observations, and individual exposures were limited to &lt;15\u201330\u2009min to minimize sky variation and cosmic-ray effects. The source exposures for programme 094.A-0115(A) (4\u00a0\u00d7 1800\u2009s) were acquired on 2014 November 20, while the exposures for programme 096.A-0710(A) (32\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0930\u2009s, 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0953\u2009s, 37\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0962\u2009s, 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0963\u2009s) were obtained in queue mode between 2015 October 8 and 2016 September 28 in 15 separate observing blocks. Each observing block was ideally composed of four equal exposures, rotated by 90\u00b0 from one another and dithered within a 1\u2009arcsec box. Observations were taken in both \u2018clear\u2019 and \u2018photometric\u2019 conditions (\u2018clear\u2019 requested), with DIMM seeing values between 0.37\u2009arcsec and 1.09\u2009arcsec (0.68\u2009arcsec median; &lt;0.8\u2009arcsec requested), airmasses between 1.09 and 1.42 (1.17 median; &lt;1.6 requested) and &lt; \u00b17\u2009d from full Moon.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Data were reduced largely following the standard procedures of the <span class=\"small-caps\">esorex</span> pipeline (muse-kit-2.4.1; Weilbacher, Streicher\u00a0&amp; Palsa <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Basic calibration files were used to perform bias subtraction and flat fielding, using illumination and twilight exposures taken closest to the date of the source exposure. Flux calibration and telluric correction were performed using the standard star taken closest to the date of the source exposure (generally but not always the same night). Spectral response curves were visually inspected for problems; all appeared reasonable and were applied to all individual cubes. Autocalibration was performed to improve IFU-to-IFU and slice-to-slice flux variations, using masks generated via Source Extractor (hereafter referred to as <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span>; Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Individual data cubes were aligned to the <em>HST F</em>814<em>W</em> reference frame using a combination of <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span>, to identify bright sources in the individual data cubes and <em>HST</em> image, and custom software, to calculate the offsets between them. <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> (Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) was applied to individual cubes to mitigate sky-line residuals. Individual data cubes were then renormalized based on photometric offset compared to point spread function (PSF)-matched <em>HST F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> images; flux offsets ranged from 0.95 to 1.08 with a median of 1.02. Finally, individual exposure-weighted cubes were stacked on a common grid to create the final mosaic.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An image highlighting the coverage of the A370 MUSE mosaic can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763403 id=\"132763403\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SPECTROSCOPY</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763404 id=\"132763404\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Spectral extraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtain spectral information for objects in the MUSE mosaic using two complementary techniques: a targeted extraction based on <em>HST</em> imaging and a \u2018blind\u2019 identification of emission lines. The full procedure is described in Mahler et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), but we briefly describe the process here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the targeted search, we identify objects by running <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> on an inverse-variance-weighted stacked image of all seven broad-band HFF filters. Prior to stacking the data, we first remove bright intracluster light from each image by subtracting the median value of a 21\u00a0\u00d7\u00a021\u00a0pixel box surrounding each point. This significantly improves the contrast between bright and faint objects, resulting in cleaner spectral extraction. The actual extraction is based on the <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> segmentation map for each object, convolved with the MUSE PSF and resampled to match its pixel scale. All MUSE spaxels that fall in this broadened mask region are combined, weighted by the signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio, and collapsed from 3D to 1D, which we take as the final spectrum of each object.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Conversely, the blind search operates on the MUSE cube directly, using <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> to detect emission lines without regard to any <em>HST</em> imaging. To do this, the program creates a series of pseudo-narrow-band images over the full MUSE wavelength range, summing the flux from five spectral bins around a given wavelength slice (spanning 6.25\u2009\u00c5) and subtracting the nearby continuum: the average of the 25\u2009\u00c5 immediately redward and blueward of the averaged narrow band. The program then runs an additional iteration of <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> on these images and notes the positions of any bright flux peaks. If multiple emission lines appear at the same spatial location, <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> attempts to fit a redshift for the object by matching it with a library of known spectral features. Otherwise, it simply reports the coordinates and wavelength of the emission line(s), which can then be inspected manually.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> operates independently of the <em>HST</em> data, many of these lines can also be seen in spectra extracted from the targeted search. Therefore, to avoid duplicate efforts while measuring redshifts (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>) we first match <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> detections to any <em>HST</em> object that falls within a 1\u2009arcsec radius of its centroid. In cases where multiple <em>HST</em> objects fall within this radius, we simply take the closest object to be the match. The average separation between the matched <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> and <em>HST</em> centroids is less than 0.1\u2009arcsec, resulting in a high likelihood that matched entries identify the same object. Never the less, we still compare the two values during redshift measurement, to make sure this is the case. While this accounts for a large fraction of lines, there are still 21 \u2018orphan\u2019 <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> detections that do not have a counterpart in the <em>HST</em><span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> catalogue. These are typically extremely faint (or continuum-free) galaxies at high redshift (<em>z</em> &gt; 3) displaying strong Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emission (e.g. Maseda et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Since the targeted extraction method does not automatically generate a spectrum for these systems, we instead create one by hand by combining all spaxels in the MUSE data within a 1\u2009arcsec radius from the <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span>-measured centroid.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763409 id=\"132763409\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Redshift measurements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Once all spectra are extracted and coincident <em>HST</em>- and <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span>-based entries are merged together, we analyse the data to measure redshifts. As an initial guess, we run the automated software <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> (Baldry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) on all extracted spectra, without regard to object size or brightness. The software attempts to find a best-fitting redshift for each spectrum using cross-correlation with user-supplied redshift templates; for templates we use a series of previously classified MUSE spectra (transformed to <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0) with prominent optical emission and absorption features, following Inami et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The correlation coefficient (cc) output by <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> provides an objective measure to determine the quality of the template match, where a value cc &gt; 5 is considered a \u2018good\u2019 fit to the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After running the automatic method, we review the results using a customized <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>-based redshifting tool that allows a user to manually refine redshifts up to \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.0001 precision, independent of the redshift. We also compare these measurements to any <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> value associated with the object. We inspect all objects down to <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 26.5 in the deeper, central region of the MUSE mosaic, and <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 25.0 in the shallower outer regions. In both cases this marks the point where continuum- or absorption-based features become too faint to be detected, and also corresponds to a steep decline in objects with an <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> cc &gt; 5. We stress however that any objects with a <span class=\"monospace\">MUSELET</span> detection or an <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> cc &gt; 5 are included in this subsample, regardless of the magnitude cut-off.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763412 id=\"132763412\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Redshift catalogue</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The final master catalogue contains 584 objects, though there are only 506 unique systems when accounting for multiple imaging of background galaxies. We identify and refine multiply imaged objects using an iterative process based on the current lens model. These steps are described in the next subsection and in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. The full catalogue spans a redshift range 0 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 6.2855 and is made up of stars, cluster members, multiply imaged galaxies, and other foreground and background interlopers. The spectral distribution and spatial location of all objects with measured redshifts can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In addition, we also provide a sample of the first few entries of the catalogue in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a>. The full catalogue is available as an <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online supplement</a></span> to the electronic version of this manuscript.</p>                        <a id=\"132763414\" scrollto-destination=\"132763414\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=0fHsR0HGVLzoJScNSLYwTOumXLmRjiONvwMlqaqrqNZGBPovETKhVU62zEh~5cWpR6DSUqdbFKMXWCDSvACz5~EmvO296MbimWgbV3q~y3IjQnh7LjYbEr6a4PlOa~tmi8irQOwh0sQSGXFEp5~XEdbHScAfdag-EUoRfWWlX0pd01dU7z8yihjCrkTswJeZtABg4M82nFyTVqSQmLllEpVxiTEDyMWEfWbTXAjhv4-oTKZoze0VGLTmyD~LZ8nYfUryjc80o4MWZbA9O4YmiONigyxu4COOKqMUwbU4tH8N-uMHHd6u46kBoVkWrd7nV369NVbyWxuA-kWPcgxVrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Spatial distribution of all objects identified in the redshift catalogue. Objects are colour-coded based on their redshift range and match the colours used in the lower panels. The RGB colour image is generated from the MUSE data itself. Bottom: redshift distribution of all objects in the catalogue (for clarity, all members of a multiply imaged object are combined into a single entry). Colours are as follows: purple \u2013 stars (z\u00a0= 0); blue \u2013 foreground galaxies (0 &lt; z &lt; 0.35); green \u2013 cluster galaxies (0.35 \u2264 z \u2264 0.4); yellow \u2013 \u2018near\u2019 background galaxies (0.4 &lt; z &lt; 1.5); orange \u2013 MUSE redshift desert (1.5 &lt; z &lt; 2.9); red \u2013 \u2018far\u2019 background galaxies (z &gt; 2.9). The colours and shading of the histogram bars are based on the spectral confidence value, as follows: plain bar \u2013 confidence 3 (high confidence); hashed bar \u2013 confidence 2 (medium confidence); grey bar \u2013 confidence 1 (low confidence). For complete spectral information, see Table\u00a0C1 and the online catalogue supplement. Details of the spectral classification (including the confidence measurement) can be found in Appendix\u00a0C.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763414/stz620fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=kR~IZkPNRcXlfYfsg7ZOx3~jMKNpOs-DB5ihGVuqskwEl2uuMmmcBHJrqBRGPAH6YF3b~ZA5AHQRKj0ThHbDnZgfGFehgRtIeo9i~eUeOgNnMTog7lFN-6CLsEoNJgf~2zUDOa3yuS1KKnz9doNQfCf9-RMPr-PyjFWqykEmHzEZtq7tP5nP2k0-6bLsydMCsGCHMT6CNltKrhPy2j7DaZmjlbIY9XkIlzru5OUFPQurqUXJyjOJSnAiAf46ZXGeJTTpYJdHS8kbP~Jsq8DyaXoXJtnlZ6Uf0oVWoqw9i1uB8Lq7wNY3vpRKCFvNb65OfetfNOL2FYhoylDM0kckAQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=132763414&amp;ar=5368372&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: Spatial distribution of all objects identified in the redshift catalogue. Objects are colour-coded based on their redshift range and match the colours used in the lower panels. The RGB colour image is generated from the MUSE data itself. Bottom: redshift distribution of all objects in the catalogue (for clarity, all members of a multiply imaged object are combined into a single entry). Colours are as follows: purple \u2013 stars (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0); blue \u2013 foreground galaxies (0 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.35); green \u2013 cluster galaxies (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4); yellow \u2013 \u2018near\u2019 background galaxies (0.4 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 1.5); orange \u2013 MUSE redshift desert (1.5 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 2.9); red \u2013 \u2018far\u2019 background galaxies (<em>z</em> &gt; 2.9). The colours and shading of the histogram bars are based on the spectral confidence value, as follows: plain bar \u2013 confidence 3 (high confidence); hashed bar \u2013 confidence 2 (medium confidence); grey bar \u2013 confidence 1 (low confidence). For complete spectral information, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a> and the <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online catalogue supplement</a></span>. Details of the spectral classification (including the confidence measurement) can be found in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">C</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=0fHsR0HGVLzoJScNSLYwTOumXLmRjiONvwMlqaqrqNZGBPovETKhVU62zEh~5cWpR6DSUqdbFKMXWCDSvACz5~EmvO296MbimWgbV3q~y3IjQnh7LjYbEr6a4PlOa~tmi8irQOwh0sQSGXFEp5~XEdbHScAfdag-EUoRfWWlX0pd01dU7z8yihjCrkTswJeZtABg4M82nFyTVqSQmLllEpVxiTEDyMWEfWbTXAjhv4-oTKZoze0VGLTmyD~LZ8nYfUryjc80o4MWZbA9O4YmiONigyxu4COOKqMUwbU4tH8N-uMHHd6u46kBoVkWrd7nV369NVbyWxuA-kWPcgxVrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: Spatial distribution of all objects identified in the redshift catalogue. Objects are colour-coded based on their redshift range and match the colours used in the lower panels. The RGB colour image is generated from the MUSE data itself. Bottom: redshift distribution of all objects in the catalogue (for clarity, all members of a multiply imaged object are combined into a single entry). Colours are as follows: purple \u2013 stars (z\u00a0= 0); blue \u2013 foreground galaxies (0 &lt; z &lt; 0.35); green \u2013 cluster galaxies (0.35 \u2264 z \u2264 0.4); yellow \u2013 \u2018near\u2019 background galaxies (0.4 &lt; z &lt; 1.5); orange \u2013 MUSE redshift desert (1.5 &lt; z &lt; 2.9); red \u2013 \u2018far\u2019 background galaxies (z &gt; 2.9).
