Because of the high magnification induced by the galaxy\u2013galaxy interaction, these objects are given an undue weight in the scaling relation, leading to a biased parameter fit.</div>                        <a id=\"132763451\" scrollto-destination=\"132763451\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=f~0HXkCZB9F~sRjlwK5unhMmq2gE2P8UtobaqAb1AFtq0XVIaHoKnVcIrgNgZfDKeoGeGs-b69pOclbUvn1Qn1B1qFs6L2zvQWuXiyt1e6vvwE0WVKIyJgofeSx8hA5cZ9~V6EISo1mxJizPT3avRVeOksCfTgj1pHdoCy-0tnpTICp5o0e2bm36OLmUlOz0hA6jTddkxRaKDmHWZcByQSdcv3hsa~Tub5MHlhor4nned3Nn2maXkaJ1h2E7BheoOOaLAJ2k7zElJpNdf4HMGBXxsu8oXfPeOxusBdAilACyorLkFfwBCPEn0CbXy6sr79p52u8xcW5Hsv7uyNmvrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass model properties. Left: differences between the final optimized haloes of the gold, silver, bronze, and copper models (colour scheme matches Fig.\u00a01.) For comparison, the final positions of the large-scale haloes in the GTO model are shown as dashed white ellipses, and those of the \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold model are shown as dashed yellow ellipses. The size of each ellipse is scaled to the halo\u2019s velocity dispersion, highlighting the relative mass of each component. The large-scale components (DM1 to DM4) show little change from model to model \u2013 thanks largely to the overwhelming number of gold-class constraints \u2013 though we do see a slight increase in ellipticity as lower-confidence multiple-image systems are added. The crown clump (DM4) shows the most variation, though its change in position is still small (typically &lt; 6\u2009arcsec). Smaller-scale masses show even less variation, and any noticeable change (such as the relative mass difference between G3 and G4) can be explained by model degeneracies. Best-fitting values for all parameters are given in Table\u00a0A1. Right: Mass density contours of the best-fitting copper-class model (green lines), along with the positions and orientations of the large-scale dark matter haloes (copper ellipses). We again stress that the ellipses are only meant to show the relative strength and shape of each halo, and are not truly representative of their mass distributions. Contours appear at steps of 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108\u2009M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122, starting at 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108\u2009M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122. Like the GTO model, the contours appear elliptical in the core, and then gradually become boxy towards the outskirts. As expected we see significant mass overdensities near the BCGs and crown galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763451/stz620fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763451\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=cx8VX1tZC4vmfcfQW9IPF1J77pE-26N7KTe8cEiXpZWfNOoZpC0ISP3ETcIkEupmbm2Uvi9Kdqje0aUzBmISabT8wYbVrQsNBDfV7dBiJKwcRd4YQ8qG-djp9VNaZ542GKHDD8K7fRuyN-8SvuOSoQ2ldxRziYGkxYaTZxJFsEif48y3CzD4S0ikh9NsoLwjx22a5Pf8AIJ3MEPN41EPOZZwTZZTV5Xy-h3ui-D8Oc8hpyDxAuvfH3Jqj5QDIb6vnmW9h0MLoL9hI1mFb5QpRAG7OKRtOuxmnxjDLRUsNoS-wtj3aJjfK1zQ5A0iOPH5aM-nYDUzigyQvs3s~e2qnw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763451&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass model properties. <em>Left:</em> differences between the final optimized haloes of the <em>gold, silver, bronze</em>, and <em>copper</em> models (colour scheme matches Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.) For comparison, the final positions of the large-scale haloes in the GTO model are shown as dashed white ellipses, and those of the \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold model are shown as dashed yellow ellipses. The size of each ellipse is scaled to the halo\u2019s velocity dispersion, highlighting the relative mass of each component. The large-scale components (DM1 to DM4) show little change from model to model \u2013 thanks largely to the overwhelming number of <em>gold</em>-class constraints \u2013 though we do see a slight increase in ellipticity as lower-confidence multiple-image systems are added. The crown clump (DM4) shows the most variation, though its change in position is still small (typically &lt; 6\u2009arcsec). Smaller-scale masses show even less variation, and any noticeable change (such as the relative mass difference between G3 and G4) can be explained by model degeneracies. Best-fitting values for all parameters are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. <em>Right:</em> Mass density contours of the best-fitting <em>copper</em>-class model (green lines), along with the positions and orientations of the large-scale dark matter haloes (copper ellipses). We again stress that the ellipses are only meant to show the relative strength and shape of each halo, and are not truly representative of their mass distributions. Contours appear at steps of 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8\u2009</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting at 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Like the GTO model, the contours appear elliptical in the core, and then gradually become boxy towards the outskirts. As expected we see significant mass overdensities near the BCGs and crown galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=f~0HXkCZB9F~sRjlwK5unhMmq2gE2P8UtobaqAb1AFtq0XVIaHoKnVcIrgNgZfDKeoGeGs-b69pOclbUvn1Qn1B1qFs6L2zvQWuXiyt1e6vvwE0WVKIyJgofeSx8hA5cZ9~V6EISo1mxJizPT3avRVeOksCfTgj1pHdoCy-0tnpTICp5o0e2bm36OLmUlOz0hA6jTddkxRaKDmHWZcByQSdcv3hsa~Tub5MHlhor4nned3Nn2maXkaJ1h2E7BheoOOaLAJ2k7zElJpNdf4HMGBXxsu8oXfPeOxusBdAilACyorLkFfwBCPEn0CbXy6sr79p52u8xcW5Hsv7uyNmvrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass model properties. Left: differences between the final optimized haloes of the gold, silver, bronze, and copper models (colour scheme matches Fig.\u00a01.) For comparison, the final positions of the large-scale haloes in the GTO model are shown as dashed white ellipses, and those of the \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold model are shown as dashed yellow ellipses. The size of each ellipse is scaled to the halo\u2019s velocity dispersion, highlighting the relative mass of each component. The large-scale components (DM1 to DM4) show little change from model to model \u2013 thanks largely to the overwhelming number of gold-class constraints \u2013 though we do see a slight increase in ellipticity as lower-confidence multiple-image systems are added. The crown clump (DM4) shows the most variation, though its change in position is still small (typically &lt; 6\u2009arcsec). Smaller-scale masses show even less variation, and any noticeable change (such as the relative mass difference between G3 and G4) can be explained by model degeneracies. Best-fitting values for all parameters are given in Table\u00a0A1. Right: Mass density contours of the best-fitting copper-class model (green lines), along with the positions and orientations of the large-scale dark matter haloes (copper ellipses). We again stress that the ellipses are only meant to show the relative strength and shape of each halo, and are not truly representative of their mass distributions. Contours appear at steps of 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108\u2009M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122, starting at 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108\u2009M\u2299\u2009kpc\u22122. Like the GTO model, the contours appear elliptical in the core, and then gradually become boxy towards the outskirts. As expected we see significant mass overdensities near the BCGs and crown galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763451/stz620fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763451\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=cx8VX1tZC4vmfcfQW9IPF1J77pE-26N7KTe8cEiXpZWfNOoZpC0ISP3ETcIkEupmbm2Uvi9Kdqje0aUzBmISabT8wYbVrQsNBDfV7dBiJKwcRd4YQ8qG-djp9VNaZ542GKHDD8K7fRuyN-8SvuOSoQ2ldxRziYGkxYaTZxJFsEif48y3CzD4S0ikh9NsoLwjx22a5Pf8AIJ3MEPN41EPOZZwTZZTV5Xy-h3ui-D8Oc8hpyDxAuvfH3Jqj5QDIb6vnmW9h0MLoL9hI1mFb5QpRAG7OKRtOuxmnxjDLRUsNoS-wtj3aJjfK1zQ5A0iOPH5aM-nYDUzigyQvs3s~e2qnw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763451&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass model properties. <em>Left:</em> differences between the final optimized haloes of the <em>gold, silver, bronze</em>, and <em>copper</em> models (colour scheme matches Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.) For comparison, the final positions of the large-scale haloes in the GTO model are shown as dashed white ellipses, and those of the \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold model are shown as dashed yellow ellipses. The size of each ellipse is scaled to the halo\u2019s velocity dispersion, highlighting the relative mass of each component. The large-scale components (DM1 to DM4) show little change from model to model \u2013 thanks largely to the overwhelming number of <em>gold</em>-class constraints \u2013 though we do see a slight increase in ellipticity as lower-confidence multiple-image systems are added. The crown clump (DM4) shows the most variation, though its change in position is still small (typically &lt; 6\u2009arcsec). Smaller-scale masses show even less variation, and any noticeable change (such as the relative mass difference between G3 and G4) can be explained by model degeneracies. Best-fitting values for all parameters are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. <em>Right:</em> Mass density contours of the best-fitting <em>copper</em>-class model (green lines), along with the positions and orientations of the large-scale dark matter haloes (copper ellipses). We again stress that the ellipses are only meant to show the relative strength and shape of each halo, and are not truly representative of their mass distributions. Contours appear at steps of 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8\u2009</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting at 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Like the GTO model, the contours appear elliptical in the core, and then gradually become boxy towards the outskirts. As expected we see significant mass overdensities near the BCGs and crown galaxies.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the multiply imaged features, we include all of the systems identified in the spectroscopic catalogue, as they provide the strongest constraints on the model. However, we also add additional systems with less secure (or missing) redshifts, as these objects can still reveal information about the cluster mass distribution. While we do not apply weights to any multiple-image constraint, we do classify images based on their overall reliability, following the convention of the HFF public modelling challenge. As part of the challenge, any modeller can suggest an image to add to the constraint set (either a known multiple image or a new candidate) and all groups then vote on the object\u2019s inclusion. Based on the results of the vote, images can be classified in one of three categories: <em>gold, silver</em>, or <em>bronze</em>, or remain uncategorized and not included in the challenge set.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images in the <em>gold</em> category are considered the most reliable constraints, with a broad agreement between groups that they are real multiple images. These systems often have a distinct and recognizable morphology and a well-defined redshift \u2013 in fact, based on the rules of the challenge a <em>gold</em>-class constraint is <em>required</em> to have a spectroscopic redshift. Similarly, <em>silver</em>-class objects are also considered reliable, but may be missing an essential component, such as a distinct morphological identification or a spectroscopic redshift. While these images can generate some disagreement between modelling groups, they are still highly ranked by a majority of teams. Constraints in the <em>bronze</em> class are less certain than the other categories \u2013 often, these images have only a tentative spectroscopic redshift and/or an unusual feature (such as a dissimilar shape or colour) that makes them appear different from their counterimages. However, there is still enough of an agreement between groups to include them in the challenge. Any remaining candidate systems (which generate even more disagreement between modelling teams) are dropped from consideration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The A370 challenge considers a total of 150 candidate lens images, gathered from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>, and the new systems presented in this work. Of all the images considered, a vast majority (103 images) are rated as <em>gold</em>-class constraints, along with a small minority of <em>silver</em>-class (12 images) and <em>bronze</em>-class (7 images) objects as well. Although there are only three categories used in the public modelling challenge, our model of A370 includes a fourth category, which we label as <em>copper</em> constraints. While these objects are not formally considered as part of the modelling challenge, their exclusion can often be explained by special circumstances, and we believe they are all real multiply imaged systems. In particular, Systems 39 and 40 and Images 15.6 and 15.7 (all of which have spectroscopic redshifts) were only discovered after the modelling challenge had finished, while System 45 (a <em>z</em> &gt; 7 dropout candidate identified by Ishigaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) was suggested too late in the process to be voted on by all groups. The remaining <em>copper</em>-class constraints (such as Images 10.3 and 11.3) have been evaluated by the modelling teams but did not receive enough favourable votes to make the final cut. In spite of this, we feel there is enough additional evidence, such as shape and multiband colour, to include these images regardless. Overall, we include 15 <em>copper</em>-class images in our model, which, when combined with all other constraints, leads to a grand total of 137 multiple-image objects in the field. The final classification of all \u2018good\u2019 objects can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the additional systems identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> were not available during the modelling challenge voting period. Since these objects have no votes and also no spectroscopic data, even here, we do not include them as model constraints. However, we use them after the fact as predictive images, in order to see if they are consistent with our new model (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3.3</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763456 id=\"132763456\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After selecting the appropriate set of model components and constraints, we input everything into <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> and proceed to measure a best-fitting mass distribution for A370. Initially we only include <em>gold</em>-class images as model constraints, as this avoids potentially biasing the fit with less reliable data. However, we progressively add additional constraints as the model develops.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763458 id=\"132763458\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 The <em>gold</em> model</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to probe as broad an area of parameter space as possible, we place large uniform priors on all variables during optimization, centring the limits of each parameter\u2019s prior on its corresponding GTO model value. Based on the results of this <em>gold</em>-model fit, we find that the shape and magnitude of the mass distribution remain broadly similar to those of the GTO model, though some individual components have significantly shifted. In particular, relative to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L17</a> the two cluster-scale mass clumps near the northern BCG rearrange themselves from a V-shaped configuration to a more linear shape, with the eastern clump moving slightly northwards, and the western clump moving farther south, creating a more obvious bridge between the northern and southern cluster haloes. The relative position angles (PAs) of these components remain the same, however, and still create boxy iso-mass contours that trace the shape of the X-ray gas. We note that the GTO V configuration is likely due to the limitations of using purely elliptical potentials, rather than a true configuration of the mass distribution, and that a linear configuration is likely closer to reality, given the orientation of the two merging clusters. Conversely, the crown clump remains largely unchanged from its GTO orientation and mass, providing further evidence for its importance in the model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We evaluate the quality of the fit by measuring the rms error of the constraint predictions, finding that \u2013 despite using more than double the number of constraints \u2013 the average rms separation only increases by a small fraction, from 0.94\u2009arcsec in the GTO model to 1.08\u2009arcsec. While this is not a poor fit overall, it is slightly larger than the 1\u2009arcsec benchmark that is often used as the minimum level of acceptable rms error. To try to improve the fit, we first attempt to add additional mass components to the system, in a similar fashion to the crown clump in the GTO model. Unlike that situation though, there are no significant \u2018bad\u2019 regions where the model predictions are highly offset from observations and thus no obvious choice for where to position a new component. Therefore, we generate several new trial configurations, placing a single additional potential at random points throughout the field \u2013 but paying particular attention to the western side of the cluster where there are no large scale clumps currently. As before, we again apply broad uniform priors on the component parameters, allowing for a considerable amount of freedom in the fit. However, after running all configurations we find that the model rejects this new clump, assigning it an unrealistically low mass (\u03c3<sub>0</sub> &lt; 100\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) and leaving the average rms unchanged.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763461 id=\"132763461\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 External shear</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As an alternative, we run the modified <em>gold</em> model again but with an external shear component taking the place of the new potential. The results of this test are significantly different from our previous trials: The new model shows a marked improvement over the original, lowering the average rms to 0.66\u2009arcsec. While the new shear term does not significantly change the total enclosed mass of the cluster, it does shift mass between various large-scale components and also affects their shapes. In particular, we notice that the two central cluster haloes (DM2 and DM3) have lower velocity dispersion parameters (by \u223c12\u00a0per\u2009cent), while the northern BCG (BCG2) and a nearby cluster member that we model independently from the scaling relation (GAL2; ID 12084) increase by roughly the same amount (\u223c15\u00a0per\u2009cent). However, this is likely due to a degeneracy between the shear and the potentials, especially in the case of GAL2, which (while likely massive) does not appear to have an unusually large radius like a BCG, nor does it show exceptionally wide absorption features \u2013 which would justify a high \u03c3<sub>0</sub> value \u2013 in its extracted spectrum. At the same time, all large haloes become noticeably rounder with the shear model (a natural consequence of including an additional \u2018stretching\u2019 term), with an average ellipticity \u03f5\u00a0= 0.35 as compared to \u03f5\u00a0= 0.60 in the shear-free model. Even with this reduction, however, we note that the haloes still maintain the same orientation and continue to drive the boxy appearance of the central mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although including shear improves the fit, the term itself presents a slight problem from a physical point of view: The nature of external shear (a constant, non-localized effect that uniformly distorts model constraints) is inherently non-physical, merely serving as a proxy for some unknown effect. While a small amount of shear can account for localized perturbations such as the intrinsic variation in galaxy-scale masses, larger values (\u0393 &gt; 0.1) point to a more significant issue, such as an unaccounted-for mass distribution or substructure \u2013 which may be located a considerable distance away from the main cluster (e.g. Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). This is the case in our <em>gold</em> model, where the magnitude of the shear term is \u0393\u00a0= 0.128. We investigate the nature of this component in the next section (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>), where we attempt to replace it with a more physically motivated feature. For now, however, we maintain the shear term in our subsequent models due to the positive impact it has on the results.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763464 id=\"132763464\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-3>4.3.3 Incorporating further lens constraints</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To explore the mass distribution further, we begin adding new constraints to the model, starting with the <em>silver</em> images, followed by the <em>bronze</em> and finally the <em>copper</em> systems. Because the total number of <em>gold</em> constraints is considerably larger than all other objects combined, the effects of the new systems are typically very small, though the total model rms error increases slightly, from 0.70\u2009arcsec in the <em>silver</em> model to 0.73\u2009arcsec in the <em>bronze</em> model and 0.78\u2009arcsec in the <em>copper</em> model. We do note, however, that incorporating new constraints near the central regions of the cluster seems to redistribute some mass from individual galaxies back to the large-scale haloes. The final positions and orientations of the large-scale haloes in all models can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. From the figure, it is clear that \u2013 despite having large freedom to vary \u2013 the cluster haloes remain generally static as the model progresses from <em>gold</em> to <em>copper</em>. While the crown clump potential (DM4) is the component most sensitive to newer constraints, its centroid moves by less than 6\u2009arcsec over all models. Given the typical centroid uncertainty of DM4 (\u223c2.5\u2009arcsec), this is consistent within 2\u03c3. Likewise, the total mass of DM4 (within a 150\u2009kpc aperture) varies by less than \u223c10\u00a0per\u2009cent, also within the range of model uncertainty.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly, we compute the radially averaged surface mass density profile for each model, starting from the midpoint between the two BCGs (\u03b1 = 39.970417, \u03b4 =\u00a0\u22121.5768056) and continuing to distances well outside the cluster core (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). Like the individual mass components we again see a good agreement between models, in terms of both absolute value and overall profile shape. In all cases the profile shows a flat central core, followed by a small bump at \u223c90\u2009kpc (corresponding to the location of the BCGs), and then a long, slowly decreasing tail.</p>                        <a id=\"132763467\" scrollto-destination=\"132763467\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=xuWRkr~Xge8VM7n2Tred-5fUKLM7N79KHZjamxrlehhfvipA6~mLY2Abf4jLZg2TH4s5RRrt335JH5a4UfTbJgThLAEZTfQbsOa3crh5lQQZKp5sPD5wpa4J7ANvdFeA8OaPr4LZB9DafCkOGAbZuajx~U7t7kd0GLLeZ6EsD7mscDx-grQYMZb3vHa6Weq6xXzIstVyBEIhWMqNzig7o8sUcfYQ-GicLcp3DVMP6PiPVnGuJyphQaJSPrfH82Ex76xPI5HLvrQT0OVBVvrQOGfZPtsxA7x7-Q4F25ahReyK7tnPdngbDOmVXBP5zmtoxb9bZwXN4oS4AsFvI4QE6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface mass density profiles of all models. In each case the best-fitting value is shown by a dark line, surrounded by a lighter shaded region representing model uncertainty. The shape of the profile is similar for all models: The surface density is largely flat in the central cluster core and then slowly diminishes at larger radii. This is also consistent with other independent models of A370 (e.g. D18), and we do expect a flat core, based on the high number of multiple images seen near the cluster centre (Section\u00a03.3.1). The sharp peak at \u223c90\u2009kpc is due to the high mass of the BCGs, which are considerably overdense compared to other components. The total magnitude of the density is also largely consistent between models in the inner cluster, given the measured errors, though the GTO and \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold models show higher densities at distances beyond 200\u2009kpc. This is because these models do not utilize a (massless) external shear term, and the discrepancy between the sheared and non-sheared models can point to the presence of additional mass components in the cluster outskirts. In the inset plot we zoom in on the central 100\u2009kpc of the cluster, better differentiating the profile shape of different models and highlighting their good statistical agreement.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763467/stz620fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763467\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=be2uXJ34ozbxAmA~9A4eEBUqZ9vsm2lFRUyDbb6Ydp-4goLY-bs2wHaKdi7GaEjdKGfLj7GELE1kCxCllsSaUJI2OynSZ28ak0PNUP0SwkF9Ped0nJ-atJ-TWhekngRylHhSxYPKFjr90JMLJKcCqhp9TYatmjF4eXkEgwTKLbydG0blskndQh74acjp9bcI2kwjdFRWUQgHfOkgcMCkUJLrwhxZTq4ZtjcQZKQREb8cxxUmU6z8H5QkQn89o-~2UtQHw2W2SB0QyKvn4qDjQtBjWeL0VObUVqmfr1BQccOEwJabVTNEuihLw6ZlNVy4f5L-G4XikkUEXOup83aVYw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763467&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface mass density profiles of all models. In each case the best-fitting value is shown by a dark line, surrounded by a lighter shaded region representing model uncertainty. The shape of the profile is similar for all models: The surface density is largely flat in the central cluster core and then slowly diminishes at larger radii. This is also consistent with other independent models of A370 (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>), and we do expect a flat core, based on the high number of multiple images seen near the cluster centre (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>). The sharp peak at \u223c90\u2009kpc is due to the high mass of the BCGs, which are considerably overdense compared to other components. The total magnitude of the density is also largely consistent between models in the inner cluster, given the measured errors, though the GTO and \u2018no-shear\u2019 <em>gold</em> models show higher densities at distances beyond 200\u2009kpc. This is because these models do not utilize a (massless) external shear term, and the discrepancy between the sheared and non-sheared models can point to the presence of additional mass components in the cluster outskirts. In the inset plot we zoom in on the central 100\u2009kpc of the cluster, better differentiating the profile shape of different models and highlighting their good statistical agreement.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=xuWRkr~Xge8VM7n2Tred-5fUKLM7N79KHZjamxrlehhfvipA6~mLY2Abf4jLZg2TH4s5RRrt335JH5a4UfTbJgThLAEZTfQbsOa3crh5lQQZKp5sPD5wpa4J7ANvdFeA8OaPr4LZB9DafCkOGAbZuajx~U7t7kd0GLLeZ6EsD7mscDx-grQYMZb3vHa6Weq6xXzIstVyBEIhWMqNzig7o8sUcfYQ-GicLcp3DVMP6PiPVnGuJyphQaJSPrfH82Ex76xPI5HLvrQT0OVBVvrQOGfZPtsxA7x7-Q4F25ahReyK7tnPdngbDOmVXBP5zmtoxb9bZwXN4oS4AsFvI4QE6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface mass density profiles of all models. In each case the best-fitting value is shown by a dark line, surrounded by a lighter shaded region representing model uncertainty. The shape of the profile is similar for all models: The surface density is largely flat in the central cluster core and then slowly diminishes at larger radii. This is also consistent with other independent models of A370 (e.g. D18), and we do expect a flat core, based on the high number of multiple images seen near the cluster centre (Section\u00a03.3.1). The sharp peak at \u223c90\u2009kpc is due to the high mass of the BCGs, which are considerably overdense compared to other components. The total magnitude of the density is also largely consistent between models in the inner cluster, given the measured errors, though the GTO and \u2018no-shear\u2019 gold models show higher densities at distances beyond 200\u2009kpc. This is because these models do not utilize a (massless) external shear term, and the discrepancy between the sheared and non-sheared models can point to the presence of additional mass components in the cluster outskirts. In the inset plot we zoom in on the central 100\u2009kpc of the cluster, better differentiating the profile shape of different models and highlighting their good statistical agreement.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763467/stz620fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763467\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=be2uXJ34ozbxAmA~9A4eEBUqZ9vsm2lFRUyDbb6Ydp-4goLY-bs2wHaKdi7GaEjdKGfLj7GELE1kCxCllsSaUJI2OynSZ28ak0PNUP0SwkF9Ped0nJ-atJ-TWhekngRylHhSxYPKFjr90JMLJKcCqhp9TYatmjF4eXkEgwTKLbydG0blskndQh74acjp9bcI2kwjdFRWUQgHfOkgcMCkUJLrwhxZTq4ZtjcQZKQREb8cxxUmU6z8H5QkQn89o-~2UtQHw2W2SB0QyKvn4qDjQtBjWeL0VObUVqmfr1BQccOEwJabVTNEuihLw6ZlNVy4f5L-G4XikkUEXOup83aVYw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763467&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface mass density profiles of all models. In each case the best-fitting value is shown by a dark line, surrounded by a lighter shaded region representing model uncertainty. The shape of the profile is similar for all models: The surface density is largely flat in the central cluster core and then slowly diminishes at larger radii. This is also consistent with other independent models of A370 (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>), and we do expect a flat core, based on the high number of multiple images seen near the cluster centre (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>). The sharp peak at \u223c90\u2009kpc is due to the high mass of the BCGs, which are considerably overdense compared to other components. The total magnitude of the density is also largely consistent between models in the inner cluster, given the measured errors, though the GTO and \u2018no-shear\u2019 <em>gold</em> models show higher densities at distances beyond 200\u2009kpc. This is because these models do not utilize a (massless) external shear term, and the discrepancy between the sheared and non-sheared models can point to the presence of additional mass components in the cluster outskirts. In the inset plot we zoom in on the central 100\u2009kpc of the cluster, better differentiating the profile shape of different models and highlighting their good statistical agreement.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Accounting for model uncertainties, the magnitudes of the profiles are largely consistent with one another, though we note that the models that do not include external shear (the <em>gold</em> no-shear model and the GTO model) have higher average densities in the cluster outskirts and beyond. This is often a consequence of including a (massless) external shear term in the model, and can signal the presence of additional mass components at larger radii (e.g. Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Measuring the logarithmic slope (d\u03a3) of the profile, we see different d\u03a3 values at different radii (though these values are again consistent between models), instead of a constant value indicating a pure power-law slope. In the region best constrained by strong lensing (50\u2009kpc &lt;<em>R</em> &lt; 350\u2009kpc) we find that the slope gradually steepens from d\u03a3 = \u22120.25 to d\u03a3 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.5. This is generally consistent with an equivalent NFW (Navarro, Frenk, and White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_921_1552800073896\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_921_1552800073896\" data-open=\"bib1_921_1552800073896\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) halo model (and an exact match at <em>R</em> \u223c 200\u2009kpc), though our values are more extreme at the edges. This can largely be attributed to the dPIE mass profile, which takes the form of a double broken power law that diverges from NFW. Specifically, the dPIE surface profile has a flatter-than-NFW core region (d\u03a3 = 0), followed by an isothermal middle (d\u03a3 = \u22121), and a steeper-than-NFW outer region (d\u03a3 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22123). Regardless of these slight changes, however, we note that our slope values are fully consistent with predictions made by \u039bCDM structure formation models (see e.g. Tasitsiomi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because the <em>copper</em> model is broadly similar to the other models and includes the largest number of lensing constraints, we subsequently adopt it as our best-fitting \u2018fiducial\u2019 model, and it is the one we use to test the effects of substructure in the next section. The major parameters of each model can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>, and we highlight the 2D mass contours of the <em>copper</em> model in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, we use the <em>copper</em> model to test the properties of the remaining lens systems presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a>. This is done by feeding the already-optimized model and the candidate multiple-image positions to <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>, allowing the software to make model-based predictions of their counterimages. By comparing the differences between the model predictions and the observed positions of the systems, we measure their rms compatibility with the model. Since all candidates lack a known redshift, for the purposes of this test we assume the best-fitting redshift values measured in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> model. After running the test, we find that the candidate multiple-image systems have an average rms error of 1.5\u2009arcsec. While this is inherently large, the result is unsurprising since the model is not specifically optimized for these objects and there is a large uncertainty on their redshift estimates. Therefore, we conclude that the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">K18</a> systems are at least marginally consistent with the model, and some (if not all) could truly provide additional model constraints. We note that follow-up data, such as secure spectroscopic redshifts, would help this investigation considerably.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a final check for missed lensing constraints, we also use <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> to predict the existence of counterimages in the <em>copper</em> model for all the remaining spectroscopically confirmed galaxies lying behind the cluster (<em>z</em> &gt; 0.4), finding that all such candidates have only single-image configurations.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=132763472 id=\"132763472\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-4>4.3.4 Complex multiple-image groups</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to teaching us about the cluster mass distribution, our best-fitting model also provides information about the multiple-image galaxies themselves. As mentioned in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.1</a>, predictions made by a developed lens model can reveal the presence of additional faint counterimages initially missed by observations. This is the case for Images 15.6 and 15.7, which lie too close to a cluster member (Object 12084) to be directly seen in imaging, and are too faint to be automatically detected by <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>. Only by following up a prediction from the initial <em>gold</em>-class model are we able to observe faint traces of emission in narrow-band imaging, which we identify as Lyman\u2009\u03b1 after manually extracting spectra from the MUSE cube, thus confirming the nature of the counterimage pair.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, model predictions can also help to \u2018match\u2019 constraint systems together, signalling that objects initially thought to be independent constraints are actually part of the same system. A prime example of this is System 37, a pair of images that is \u2013 coincidentally \u2013 also located near Object 12084. Initially identified as a simple galaxy\u2013galaxy lens pair in the north of the cluster, our updated mass model predicts three additional counterimages in the south, which happen to coincide with the positions of System 19. Likewise, the three images in System 19 also predict additional counterimages that match to the positions of System 37. While the redshifts of the two systems are slightly different (<em>z</em><sub>Sys19</sub>\u00a0= 5.6493;\u2009<em>z</em><sub>Sys37</sub>\u00a0= 5.6489), they are within measurement uncertainty, and the spectra of both show similar shapes in their Lyman\u2009\u03b1 profiles (Fig.\u00a0B1). Unfortunately, contamination from intracluster light (from the BCG and Object 12084) makes an appearance match between Systems 19 and 37 impossible in the HFF imaging. However, given the strong spectral and model evidence, it is very likely that the two systems are one and the same. To test this, we run a new <em>gold</em> model where we explicitly designate the images of System 37 to be part of System 19 (as Images 19.4 and 19.5, respectively) and find that the end result is identical (within uncertainty) to the model where the two systems are kept separate. This further supports our theory. Although we could in principle change the labelling of System 37 based on this test, we choose to keep the original numbering scheme (with separate Systems 19 and 37) in order to keep our results in line with others based on the public modelling challenge.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly, we use model predictions to investigate Systems 7 and 10, which may also be linked together. This possibility is presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>, who find that by decreasing the mass-to-light ratio of the two BCGs (which subsequently reduces the dark matter content of the galaxies), their model is able to fit all counterimages of both systems using a single source galaxy. This is a particularly intriguing possibility, not only because a combined System 7\u00a0+\u00a010 would create yet another system with a large number of counterimages (<em>n</em> &gt; 5) and one with multiple radial arcs, but also because the proposed solution \u2013 a BCG that is significantly depleted of dark matter \u2013 would be at odds with <em>N</em>-body simulations and may challenge our understanding of BCG formation history (e.g. Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Laporte\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although we keep the two systems separate in our <em>copper</em> model, we find that they fall very close to one another in the source plane, with predicted counterimages of System 7 overlapping the positions of System 10 and vice versa. Thus, given their identical redshifts and similar <em>HST</em> colours and appearance, the joint-image theory seems plausible. Unlike <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>, our model does not need to alter the mass content of the BCGs for this match to work, as we still fit massive haloes around each galaxy. However, our results do modify the configuration of System 10: Rather than a merging pair of images near the northern BCG (Images 10.1 and 10.2), the model instead predicts a single, highly stretched component at the same location. Because the actual image seen in the HFF data is considerably distorted, it is difficult to identify any distinct morphological markers that could verify whether we are seeing a single galaxy image or a merging pair. We note, though, that a merging-pair solution would require the critical curve of our model (which would, in that case, bisect the two images) to shift from its current position by a large amount (&gt;2\u2009arcsec), which is significantly greater than the rms uncertainty of the fit.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763477 id=\"132763477\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUBSTRUCTURE: A REPLACEMENT FOR EXTERNAL SHEAR?</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As previously mentioned, a large external shear term can signal the presence of substructure or other unidentified mass in the vicinity of the main cluster. To investigate this possibility in A370, we look for conceivable substructures in the data, with the goal of replacing the shear with a more physically motivated component. Of all the possible candidates, the most obvious choice is the moderate overdensity of galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 1, containing 33 galaxies spanning the narrow redshift range 1.03 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 1.09, including the intriguing ring-like galaxy (ID 10287) first identified in Soucail et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>). At first glance, this appears to agree well with the background group identified in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> (30 objects between <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.0 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.1) using GLASS spectroscopy. However, after cross-checking with MUSE data we find that several members of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a> group have been misidentified or have incorrect redshifts. Specifically, six of these galaxies are more clearly identified in MUSE as low-redshift (<em>z</em> &lt; 0.6) systems (MUSE IDs: 5263, 7115, 9336, 9914, 10544, and 14179), while four other sets of \u2018close-pair\u2019 galaxies are simply separate components of highly clumpy spirals. Furthermore, we also notice that three members of the group are in fact the three images of Multiple Image System 6 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.0633), which should only count as a single object. Eliminating the false detections reduces the total number of GLASS systems to 18. Of these, 15 lie in the MUSE footprint and we are able to confirm that their redshifts are indeed in the correct range. The remaining three galaxies lie slightly outside of the MUSE field, so we are unable to independently verify their redshifts. However, looking at these systems in the HFF data, we find that two objects (GLASS IDs 1982 and 3004) appear as faint blue clumps with similar colours and morphologies to many confirmed galaxies in the group, while the third (GLASS ID 1230) is red and elliptical, with an appearance closer to the galaxies rejected by MUSE. Therefore, we include the two blue objects in the final group but reject the red galaxy, which we note is flagged in GLASS as having a low spectral quality (<em>Q</em>\u00a0= 1). Adding in the remaining MUSE-identified systems that do not appear in the GLASS catalogue (18 galaxies), we include 35 galaxies in total for the final substructure sample. The observed positions of these objects are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132763479\" scrollto-destination=\"132763479\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=u2e745z4IIeVJeA5bsL~WMf2yuIvleaG7~A0MX7mzm3IIDz6uApwtleS9JmktMOvlMDMulHrV~VQKwUVbhArR8mS6d~jQ2oJkIdWGMjVWXvL6ZbolSa-J61XhaxE2KSgjMsoxM58s8JPl77YkME5iJn3q33E6QMjNCYxNqsqrYc1MthNJXkoxB83Bt13zm~MftRWtUb1GosgCjGeKeu3H5JFfcscLOZGUYGbElXPN9KqyZSPtym-P51uAANeXN7l6eWqAdjo~UDv7E004LVqaVHHkLb2b5bRj-JCQeOH~Ds~Q9Xn7GSMWMS3leTku1~3s7J8t-FgJsvMWDOGmtUkYw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Line-of-sight substructure candidates. Left: objects in the overdense spectral bin (z \u223c 1.05) behind A370. Image-plane positions of all galaxies are shown as blue circles, while their subsequent source-plane locations (assuming the best-fitting copper model) are shown in red. The three counterimages of System 6 (which also falls in this redshift range) and its source-plane location are instead shown as yellow and orange squares. We investigate the effects of line-of-sight substructure by including these systems as additional components in the mass model (Section\u00a05.) The green circle highlights the extent of the group in the source plane, and serves as the centroid of a group-scale mass component. Right: substructure candidates in the foreground of A370. We identify two distinct groups in the redshift catalogue, at z \u223c 0.256 (cyan circles) and z \u223c 0.326 (magenta circles). The positions of the galaxies are consistent with the orientation of the external shear term in the model, and we note that many fall near the location of the crown mass clump, which raises the possibility that they could be responsible for one or both components. However, much like their background counterparts, these systems have low mass and we find that they do not significantly affect the total mass model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763479/stz620fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763479\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=Fh1ULHSNF04B-y7ZJKXSkNMzTky1z0tx-KZ~2~0Thw5egc0DweKlcdQNF0SeT~zCnPsubwPqWGEEmAn4HYCBn29u6MaqsGLmyP3sYJiyv7i0mG77c4DdtYY6wDSTG8-yzhKUvrmhhdc4CHd6-uzBVO07K8HMwjdNJ6o65dRNYcyaap3snNktptVTFq1AK5OyQwQSdFYwDKwoR4GE6OlvY11v5BvHrYmKynYVGpS0CUm2AgXssOKnnYxMVBOtPKTLWYHBe7EHqnHUpjuFVRnjwN6~PXkd-o2u7hscb9ZQmQrAwUe-zKWC~lNFHZurFN96oOH3fLWQM1gxOfglFmoFOg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763479&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Line-of-sight substructure candidates. <em>Left:</em> objects in the overdense spectral bin (<em>z</em> \u223c 1.05) behind A370. Image-plane positions of all galaxies are shown as blue circles, while their subsequent source-plane locations (assuming the best-fitting <em>copper</em> model) are shown in red. The three counterimages of System 6 (which also falls in this redshift range) and its source-plane location are instead shown as yellow and orange squares. We investigate the effects of line-of-sight substructure by including these systems as additional components in the mass model (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.) The green circle highlights the extent of the group in the source plane, and serves as the centroid of a group-scale mass component. <em>Right:</em> substructure candidates in the foreground of A370. We identify two distinct groups in the redshift catalogue, at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.256 (cyan circles) and <em>z</em> \u223c 0.326 (magenta circles). The positions of the galaxies are consistent with the orientation of the external shear term in the model, and we note that many fall near the location of the crown mass clump, which raises the possibility that they could be responsible for one or both components. However, much like their background counterparts, these systems have low mass and we find that they do not significantly affect the total mass model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=u2e745z4IIeVJeA5bsL~WMf2yuIvleaG7~A0MX7mzm3IIDz6uApwtleS9JmktMOvlMDMulHrV~VQKwUVbhArR8mS6d~jQ2oJkIdWGMjVWXvL6ZbolSa-J61XhaxE2KSgjMsoxM58s8JPl77YkME5iJn3q33E6QMjNCYxNqsqrYc1MthNJXkoxB83Bt13zm~MftRWtUb1GosgCjGeKeu3H5JFfcscLOZGUYGbElXPN9KqyZSPtym-P51uAANeXN7l6eWqAdjo~UDv7E004LVqaVHHkLb2b5bRj-JCQeOH~Ds~Q9Xn7GSMWMS3leTku1~3s7J8t-FgJsvMWDOGmtUkYw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Line-of-sight substructure candidates. Left: objects in the overdense spectral bin (z \u223c 1.05) behind A370. Image-plane positions of all galaxies are shown as blue circles, while their subsequent source-plane locations (assuming the best-fitting copper model) are shown in red. The three counterimages of System 6 (which also falls in this redshift range) and its source-plane location are instead shown as yellow and orange squares. We investigate the effects of line-of-sight substructure by including these systems as additional components in the mass model (Section\u00a05.) The green circle highlights the extent of the group in the source plane, and serves as the centroid of a group-scale mass component. Right: substructure candidates in the foreground of A370. We identify two distinct groups in the redshift catalogue, at z \u223c 0.256 (cyan circles) and z \u223c 0.326 (magenta circles). The positions of the galaxies are consistent with the orientation of the external shear term in the model, and we note that many fall near the location of the crown mass clump, which raises the possibility that they could be responsible for one or both components. However, much like their background counterparts, these systems have low mass and we find that they do not significantly affect the total mass model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763479/stz620fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763479\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=Fh1ULHSNF04B-y7ZJKXSkNMzTky1z0tx-KZ~2~0Thw5egc0DweKlcdQNF0SeT~zCnPsubwPqWGEEmAn4HYCBn29u6MaqsGLmyP3sYJiyv7i0mG77c4DdtYY6wDSTG8-yzhKUvrmhhdc4CHd6-uzBVO07K8HMwjdNJ6o65dRNYcyaap3snNktptVTFq1AK5OyQwQSdFYwDKwoR4GE6OlvY11v5BvHrYmKynYVGpS0CUm2AgXssOKnnYxMVBOtPKTLWYHBe7EHqnHUpjuFVRnjwN6~PXkd-o2u7hscb9ZQmQrAwUe-zKWC~lNFHZurFN96oOH3fLWQM1gxOfglFmoFOg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763479&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Line-of-sight substructure candidates. <em>Left:</em> objects in the overdense spectral bin (<em>z</em> \u223c 1.05) behind A370. Image-plane positions of all galaxies are shown as blue circles, while their subsequent source-plane locations (assuming the best-fitting <em>copper</em> model) are shown in red. The three counterimages of System 6 (which also falls in this redshift range) and its source-plane location are instead shown as yellow and orange squares. We investigate the effects of line-of-sight substructure by including these systems as additional components in the mass model (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.) The green circle highlights the extent of the group in the source plane, and serves as the centroid of a group-scale mass component. <em>Right:</em> substructure candidates in the foreground of A370. We identify two distinct groups in the redshift catalogue, at <em>z</em> \u223c 0.256 (cyan circles) and <em>z</em> \u223c 0.326 (magenta circles). The positions of the galaxies are consistent with the orientation of the external shear term in the model, and we note that many fall near the location of the crown mass clump, which raises the possibility that they could be responsible for one or both components. However, much like their background counterparts, these systems have low mass and we find that they do not significantly affect the total mass model.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a first test we simply include all group members as additional galaxy-scale potentials, while leaving the external shear term in place. Mirroring the procedure for the cluster members, we employ a second mass-traces-light scaling relation (equation <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">1</a>) for the background group, in order to keep the total number of model parameters manageable. We normalize this relation to the median redshift of the group (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.0494), determining a normalization constant (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 21.45) based on the behaviour of <em>L</em>* with redshift presented in Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Since this model includes masses at two distinct redshifts, we use a modified version of <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> to optimize the distribution, designed to account for multiple lensing deflections along the line of sight. Specifically, the \u2018multiplane\u2019 setting of <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> first transforms the observed coordinates of the background group members (which are themselves deflected by the cluster) to their intrinsic source positions before including the mass in the model fit, providing a more accurate description of the mass distribution. This in turn creates a more realistic light path for the observed system: Flux from the distant lensing constraints first reaches the plane of the background group, where it is lensed and deflected by the group mass. The deflected source light and undeflected group light then travel together to the cluster plane, where everything is subsequently deflected again by the cluster mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After optimizing the new configuration, we find that the additional potentials do slightly improve the fit (rms \u00a0=\u00a00.75\u2009arcsec; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>) but the model assigns only a small amount of mass to the new potentials and maintains a high-magnitude external shear term. Therefore, to test for possible degeneracies between shear and substructure mass, we run a second version of the model that eliminates the shear term entirely. Without the shear, the model quickly reverts to a configuration closer to the no-shear <em>gold</em>-class model, with a large rms value and a poorer overall fit. This suggests that the background galaxies alone are not massive enough to account for the observed model distortions; this result is perhaps unsurprising, given that the identified group galaxies are typically much smaller and fainter than the cluster members.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Alternatively, we model the group with a large-scale mass component. Taking advantage of the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> multiplane ray-tracing capability, we replace the individual galaxies in the <em>z</em> \u223c 1 scaling relation with a single massive potential representing the group halo. This allows us to not only test for an alternative to shear but also assess the likelihood that the group members are truly gravitationally bound. Since <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> currently forces background components to have a fixed lens-plane position, we place the halo at the group centroid, determined by averaging over the individual coordinates of all group members (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>). Similarly, we fix its redshift to the group median, <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.054. Given the uniform spatial distribution of the group members, we assume a circular rather than an elliptical shape for this component, though we maintain a radial profile that behaves like a dPIE potential. We note that these parameter choices are largely driven by the MUSE data, and that it is possible additional group members may reside outside of the MUSE footprint, leading to a change in centroid and redshift. However, given the flexibility of the multiplane model \u2013 by calculating the group centroid in the image plane, the component still moves relative to the cluster in the source plane \u2013 the effects of these possible systematics should have only a small effect on the results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After running two new models in this configuration \u2013 with and without the external shear term \u2013 we again find that the background group has little impact on the overall model, failing to significantly reduce the shear term when it is included or provide a viable alternative in its absence. Furthermore, the low total mass of the component (\u03c3<sub>0</sub> \u223c 200\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) makes it unlikely to be large enough to bind the individual group members together, implying that the \u2018group\u2019 is simply a chance alignment of several unrelated galaxies. We note, though, that the extended nature of the profile makes it more susceptible to degeneracies with other components. This is particularly true of the central large-scale potentials (DM2 and DM3) that make up the cluster mass distribution, which are both largely coincident on the group position. Even accounting for possible degeneracies, however, the fact remains that no combination of background galaxies or halo terms is able to significantly alter the external shear component, strongly suggesting that these masses are not the main driver of the additional model perturbations. We are therefore forced to look at other possibilities.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The two small overdensities in the foreground of A370 (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3.3</a>) stand as another logical choice, as both groups show some evidence of clustering (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>), and many of the galaxies are located to the east or west of the main cluster centre \u2013 regions where additional mass would be expected given the orientation of the external shear term (\u0393<sub>\u03b8</sub> \u223c \u221218\u00b0). However, most objects in these groups appear small and faint in HFF imaging, implying that they have low masses and thus a limited range of influence on the model. While low-mass systems make for poor lenses in any circumstance, lying close to an already massive lensing cluster enhances the effect: Even assuming these objects have masses equal to a typical cluster member, their deflection angles relative to the cluster plane are only expected to be 0.3\u2009arcsec. Since the foreground galaxies are on average over 3\u2009arcsec away from \u2018nearby\u2019 lensing constraints, it is unlikely that they will significantly perturb the constraint coordinates, especially not in a coherent fashion that mimics external shear. Furthermore, the sparse number of objects in each group (8 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.256 and 14 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.326) suggests that any halo binding the objects together is itself a low-mass system that is far less significant than the existing physical components. Never the less, we run an additional model that includes all foreground galaxies in both groups. Given the small line-of-sight separation between these objects and the main cluster, we simply add them directly to the existing <em>L</em>*-based scaling relation, instead of generating a new, separate relation. However, to account for the fact that foreground objects have a less efficient lensing effect, we renormalize their fluxes by the ratio of luminosity distances (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$R = D_{L,\\rm group}/D_{L,\\rm cluster})$|</span> making them slightly fainter (and thus, less massive) during the fitting process. As expected, we find that the model is unchanged relative to the <em>copper</em>-class model, and we reject the foreground deflectors as a suitable replacement for the shear. In doing so, we effectively eliminate all sources of line-of-sight substructure as strong model perturbers, though we note that they do have some influence on the final fit. This agrees with the results presented in Chiriv\u00ec et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), who find that including line-of-sight galaxies slightly improves the model of MACS0416, but not enough to significantly modify the final parameters of the main cluster mass components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While our current analysis shows that line-of-sight substructures do not play a large role in the A370 mass model, it does not address physically related structures farther away from the cluster core. As shown in Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), these components can dramatically impact the cluster mass environment, and in some cases act in place of external shear (e.g. Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Though outside the focus of this paper, follow-up on such structures would be particularly interesting. Indeed, there is already some evidence that additional mass structures in the outskirts of A370 may exist: Lower-resolution imaging data taken with CFH12K (Hoekstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> on the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) show several concentrations of galaxies with similar colours to cluster members (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>), and early CFHT/PUMA and ESO/PUMA2 spectroscopy (Fort et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>) tentatively measures redshifts for a few of these objects, placing them at the same distance as the cluster (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>). The east- or west-of-centre locations of these concentrations are also promising in terms of external shear replacement, since despite being at greater distances from the cluster, their potentially much larger masses could have a stronger effect. The current low-resolution imaging and sparse spectroscopy do not allow us to investigate this possibility, though future data will improve these prospects significantly. The upcoming wider field-of-view BUFFALO imaging of A370 will provide deep multiband imaging of these groups, while an upcoming wide-area MUSE mosaic designed to overlap the BUFFALO imaging will bring high-resolution spectroscopy, providing secure redshifts for all group members. With this additional data in hand, we will be in a much better position to investigate substructure in the A370 field.</p>                        <a id=\"132763486\" scrollto-destination=\"132763486\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=fwqj0wEu68uHnKe-5fou21np253mkuF0LV~V2F~7SAVizBOc7kq39GKry5WIKOFwlgKUdP1abeZuJnACi5WxpB6q-JMlp8LzrZeCmWdlZf0oiu7IsEeFLh8JgxeJOKpAXd7lvxWohcuscSHfAftgvi7WUU0ZcyJ02tw4egxqf-O7-V5Uw1yNm7gUy5~w9RlfUGM94a9~~2dhysn7ntPs3xK2E5VpSSNNQYbgaltYp30Pnsdkd96H2mBKqufS5iNHOVzrpxSroR32qAul~OaZM9iNPxAUrSQ509LESv9GO7zIfaUfIMDJ5AaozN~gxZTQmK~ScB7n~Brm3MFwv3V2cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"CFH12K imaging of A370 and its surroundings. Using multiband (B + R\u00a0+\u00a0I) photometry, we identify members of the cluster red sequence, smoothing the light from these galaxies to observe any extended structure they create (blue contours). While the majority of the light falls in the core of the cluster (seen at the image centre), we do find other concentrations at extended distances \u2013 especially in the north-west and south-east. Low-resolution PUMA spectroscopy taken throughout the field reveals that at least some of the galaxies in these extended regions have confirmed cluster redshifts (magenta circles), suggesting they could be additional substructure candidates. The black dashed circle has a radius of 1.5\u2009Mpc and serves as a rough estimate of the A370 virial radius, showing that these structures fall well within the theoretical cluster boundary. For reference, the extent of the MUSE and HFF footprints are shown in yellow and green, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763486/stz620fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763486\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=wGoeYT239aD9y9wXz4hDgT5F6g3uHSCG5GeS7oBXW3QJBnHU1kwxv-TvVhI6v20DJq6oDpyEwgzKqoyALHLq6gZcfWNtu00Uipr0PWbg-HeJoxjtj3z8KGZkGA7pmduy5DvA0D2ZeJdqBwAkQZcxYV7shZBhMO1Y4pMWiT4aezujKlSYQ9L2yQPWuP6aQ22zUh-Xs9wZ8AFtD5H9QbCasEvu2~qPGrSXShi8VHediubC9c34JsFpE12y4Lul0zcwCrArirpQ0u~lr4fTeWLeZ9ECees9EVT8ZUNrCIu3rakP6JppvqOBF~uR-dISCLg0j6jFZY5vhMgB3FDEVmGaLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763486&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">CFH12K imaging of A370 and its surroundings. Using multiband (<em>B</em> + <em>R</em>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>I</em>) photometry, we identify members of the cluster red sequence, smoothing the light from these galaxies to observe any extended structure they create (blue contours). While the majority of the light falls in the core of the cluster (seen at the image centre), we do find other concentrations at extended distances \u2013 especially in the north-west and south-east. Low-resolution PUMA spectroscopy taken throughout the field reveals that at least some of the galaxies in these extended regions have confirmed cluster redshifts (magenta circles), suggesting they could be additional substructure candidates. The black dashed circle has a radius of 1.5\u2009Mpc and serves as a rough estimate of the A370 virial radius, showing that these structures fall well within the theoretical cluster boundary. For reference, the extent of the MUSE and HFF footprints are shown in yellow and green, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/m_stz620fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=fwqj0wEu68uHnKe-5fou21np253mkuF0LV~V2F~7SAVizBOc7kq39GKry5WIKOFwlgKUdP1abeZuJnACi5WxpB6q-JMlp8LzrZeCmWdlZf0oiu7IsEeFLh8JgxeJOKpAXd7lvxWohcuscSHfAftgvi7WUU0ZcyJ02tw4egxqf-O7-V5Uw1yNm7gUy5~w9RlfUGM94a9~~2dhysn7ntPs3xK2E5VpSSNNQYbgaltYp30Pnsdkd96H2mBKqufS5iNHOVzrpxSroR32qAul~OaZM9iNPxAUrSQ509LESv9GO7zIfaUfIMDJ5AaozN~gxZTQmK~ScB7n~Brm3MFwv3V2cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"CFH12K imaging of A370 and its surroundings. Using multiband (B + R\u00a0+\u00a0I) photometry, we identify members of the cluster red sequence, smoothing the light from these galaxies to observe any extended structure they create (blue contours). While the majority of the light falls in the core of the cluster (seen at the image centre), we do find other concentrations at extended distances \u2013 especially in the north-west and south-east. Low-resolution PUMA spectroscopy taken throughout the field reveals that at least some of the galaxies in these extended regions have confirmed cluster redshifts (magenta circles), suggesting they could be additional substructure candidates. The black dashed circle has a radius of 1.5\u2009Mpc and serves as a rough estimate of the A370 virial radius, showing that these structures fall well within the theoretical cluster boundary. For reference, the extent of the MUSE and HFF footprints are shown in yellow and green, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132763486/stz620fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132763486\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263050&Signature=wGoeYT239aD9y9wXz4hDgT5F6g3uHSCG5GeS7oBXW3QJBnHU1kwxv-TvVhI6v20DJq6oDpyEwgzKqoyALHLq6gZcfWNtu00Uipr0PWbg-HeJoxjtj3z8KGZkGA7pmduy5DvA0D2ZeJdqBwAkQZcxYV7shZBhMO1Y4pMWiT4aezujKlSYQ9L2yQPWuP6aQ22zUh-Xs9wZ8AFtD5H9QbCasEvu2~qPGrSXShi8VHediubC9c34JsFpE12y4Lul0zcwCrArirpQ0u~lr4fTeWLeZ9ECees9EVT8ZUNrCIu3rakP6JppvqOBF~uR-dISCLg0j6jFZY5vhMgB3FDEVmGaLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132763486&ar=5368372&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz620fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">CFH12K imaging of A370 and its surroundings. Using multiband (<em>B</em> + <em>R</em>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>I</em>) photometry, we identify members of the cluster red sequence, smoothing the light from these galaxies to observe any extended structure they create (blue contours).
