While the majority of the light falls in the core of the cluster (seen at the image centre), we do find other concentrations at extended distances \u2013 especially in the north-west and south-east. Low-resolution PUMA spectroscopy taken throughout the field reveals that at least some of the galaxies in these extended regions have confirmed cluster redshifts (magenta circles), suggesting they could be additional substructure candidates. The black dashed circle has a radius of 1.5\u2009Mpc and serves as a rough estimate of the A370 virial radius, showing that these structures fall well within the theoretical cluster boundary. For reference, the extent of the MUSE and HFF footprints are shown in yellow and green, respectively.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763487 id=\"132763487\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work we have continued our investigation into the strong-lensing cluster Abell 370, expanding on our initial GTO study (Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) thanks to a larger mosaic of high-resolution MUSE spectroscopy and deeper <em>HST</em> imaging. As part of these efforts we have constructed a comprehensive redshift catalogue covering the full line-of-sight region in the vicinity of the cluster core. This catalogue, which is significantly more complete than the GTO edition, has considerable legacy value in its own right, and we highlight the fact that many of the redshifts published in this catalogue \u2013 already provided internally to other lens-modelling groups as part of the <em>Hubble</em> Frontier Fields modelling challenge \u2013 have proven useful in other modelling efforts (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D18</a>; Strait et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Our main results are as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The new redshift catalogue contains 584 entries, including 506 independent objects when accounting for multiple-imaging effects. With 11 stars, 57 foreground galaxies, 244 cluster members, 155 background galaxies, and 39 multiply imaged systems, this catalogue provides a 3D picture of the central cluster and its immediate surroundings.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE spectroscopic data cover nearly the entire multiple-image region of A370, allowing the identification of several new multiply imaged galaxies and more than doubling the number of spectroscopically confirmed systems. These include a number of faint or continuum-free Lyman\u2009\u03b1 emitters that are \u2018invisible\u2019 in broad-band imaging. In addition, we confirm and refine the redshifts of non-spectroscopic galaxies identified in earlier works.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the significant increase in multiple-image constraints, we are able to probe the A370 mass distribution out to larger radii, and with much greater accuracy. Given the abundance of high-confidence \u2018<em>gold</em>-class\u2019 spectroscopic constraints, we find little difference between our initial (<em>gold</em>) model and subsequent trials (<em>silver, bronze</em>, and <em>copper</em>) using additional, lower-confidence systems \u2013 though these small variations demonstrate the level of systematic uncertainty. Our final <em>copper</em>-class model contains 45 background galaxies creating 136 individual multiple-image constraints. The best-fitting rms is 0.78\u2009arcsec, a significant improvement over the GTO model (rms \u00a0=\u00a00.94\u2009arcsec).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Broadly, this model confirms the results of our GTO work: namely the boxy shape of the central mass distribution and the need for an additional mass clump (the \u2018crown\u2019 clump) in the north-east of the cluster. However, to achieve an acceptable fit level, we must include a significant external shear component, which is inherently non-physical. The presence of shear suggests additional mass not incorporated into the current model and could indicate the presence of local substructure.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the redshift catalogue, we identify three possible substructure candidates along the immediate line of sight: two small concentrations of galaxies in the foreground (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.256 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.326) and one larger group in the background (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 1.049). While the relative locations of these objects are consistent with the orientation of the best-fitting shear term, subsequent analysis shows that they are not massive enough to completely account for the shear. Never the less, we find that including the galaxies in the background group as individual haloes in the mass model slightly improves the overall fit, reducing the total rms to 0.75\u2009arcsec.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although we rule out line-of-sight substructure as the cause of shear, we are able to identify promising substructure candidates at the cluster redshift but at much greater distances from the core. An upcoming extension of our current MUSE mosaic designed to provide spectroscopic follow-up of the BUFFALO imaging campaign will target these regions, providing valuable insight into both the nature of these mass concentrations and the overall matter distribution of A370 itself.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These results showcase the advantages of our updated MUSE data set: With a deeper spectroscopic mosaic we discover several new multiply imaged constraints and evidence of structure along the line of sight, both of which improve the lens model and reveal a more complex mass distribution in the form of external shear. However, they also highlight limitations to the current approach: Despite a larger coverage area, we still focus our efforts primarily on the multiple-image region alone, which prevents us from definitively identifying the source of the external shear term and leaving an important question unresolved. It is clear, therefore, that there is a benefit in acquiring additional MUSE data in the outskirts of the cluster. Spectroscopic coverage in these regions will unambiguously identify additional substructures and give a rough estimate of their masses, eliminating the uncertainty in the current model. At the same time, an extended MUSE footprint can aid complementary studies to our own, such as a weak-lensing analysis of the mass distribution. In particular, spectroscopic data will help to calibrate the selection function of background galaxies, removing foreground interlopers that dilute the weak-lensing signal. Additionally, these data provide a more precise measure of the 3D separation between cluster and background objects, better normalizing the derived weak-lensing mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While joint strong- and weak-lensing techniques have already been used to investigate cluster properties (e.g. Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Strait et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), these studies often lack significant, wide-ranging spectroscopic coverage, especially in the weak-lensing regime. Given the different data requirements for these techniques, it is likely that a \u2018wedding cake\u2019 style survey \u2013 deeper coverage in the cluster core to identify strong lensing constraints, plus shallower coverage in the surrounding areas to identify substructure and calibrate weak lensing constraints \u2013 represents the most efficient method for analysing the cluster mass with such data. Indeed, this is the strategy we are adopting in our efforts to extend the current A370 MUSE mosaic, which we will report on in future work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we also point out that this type of coverage would be equally useful for the other FF clusters, or indeed any massive cluster with significant lensing features. A joint analysis of several clusters would be less susceptible to the effects of cosmic variance, providing more robust constraints on the substructure fraction and mass assembly history of the Universe\u2019s large-scale structure. With wide-area spectral data now more easily available thanks to MUSE and other instruments, obtaining such a sample is well within the realm of possibility, and would be well worth the effort.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763492 id=\"132763492\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the referee for a thorough read-through of the manuscript and for providing helpful comments and suggestions, which improved the clarity and content of the work. DJL, JR, BC, GM, DC, JM, and VP acknowledge support from the ERC Starting Grant 336736-CALENDS. FEB acknowledges support from the Comisi\u00f3n Nacional de Investigac\u00edon Cient\u00edfica y Tecnol\u00f3gico (CONICYT) grants Basal-CATA PFB-06/2007 and AFB-170002, Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo Cient\u00edfico y Tecnol\u00f3gico (FONDECYT) Regular 1141218, Programa de Cooperaci\u00f3n Cient\u00edfica ECOS-CONICYT C16U02, and the Ministry of Economy, Development, and Tourism\u2019s Millennium Science Initiative through grant IC120009, awarded to The Millennium Institute of Astrophysics. Some of the data presented in this paper were based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) at the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. Also based on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under programme IDs 094.A-0115 and 096.A-0710. This work utilizes gravitational lensing models produced by PIs Brada\u010d, Natarajan\u00a0&amp; Kneib (CATS), Merten\u00a0&amp; Zitrin, Sharon, Williams, Keeton, Bernstein, and Diego, and the GLAFIC group. This lens modelling was partially funded by the <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields programme conducted by STScI.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132763494 id=\"132763494\" content-id=\"bib3\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib3\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib3\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib3\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib3\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib3\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"crossref\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201425419\" class=\"link link-crossref openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></span></p>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib4\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib4\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib4\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib4\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib4\" class=\"ref-content \" C.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zabludoff</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. I.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ammons</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S. W.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Gonzalez</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. H.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2013</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">769</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">52</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/769/1/52\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1088/0004-637X/769/1/52</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"crossref\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/769/1/52\" class=\"link link-crossref openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></span></p>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763504 id=\"132763504\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX A: LENS MODELS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The best-fitting parameters of all mass models generated by this work are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. In addition to the final parameters, we also provide several goodness-of-fit criteria in the leftmost column. These include the total model rms (in arcseconds), the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> per degree of freedom (\u03bd), the maximum model likelihood (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {L}$|\u2060</span>), and model evidence (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {E}$|\u2060</span>). Furthermore, we calculate the Bayesian information criterion (BIC), taking into account the total number of model constraints (<em>n</em>) and the total number of fit parameters (<em>k</em>).</p>                        <a id=\"132763506\" scrollto-destination=\"132763506\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblA1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.97134, \u03b4 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.5822597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf17\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf17\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>b</sup></em>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> \u2212 <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> + <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf18\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf18\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf19\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf19\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Statistics notes: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> represents the model likelihood and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {E}$|</span> the model evidence. BIC is the Bayesian information criterion. The total number of model constraints is given by <em>n</em>, while <em>k</em> represents the total number of model parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132763506\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblA1\" data-id=\"tblA1\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens models and best-fitting parameters.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b1<em><sup>a</sup></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.97134, \u03b4 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.5822597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf17\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf17\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>b</sup></em>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> \u2212 <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> + <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf18\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf18\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf19\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf19\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Statistics notes: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> represents the model likelihood and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {E}$|</span> the model evidence. BIC is the Bayesian information criterion. The total number of model constraints is given by <em>n</em>, while <em>k</em> represents the total number of model parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132763506\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763507 id=\"132763507\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX B: MULTIPLE-IMAGE CUT-OUT FIGURES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This section presents cut-out images of all multiple-image systems used in this work, to better show their morphology and (in the case of systems with spectroscopic redshifts) their relative line strengths. Systems with confirmed spectroscopic redshifts are shown in Fig.\u00a0B1, while those without can be seen in Fig.\u00a0B2. (Both figures are included as electronic, <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online supplements</a></span> to this manuscript.)</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132763509 id=\"132763509\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX C: MASTER REDSHIFT TABLE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblC1\" data-open=\"tblC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a> shows a portion of the master redshift catalogue compiled in this work. This is only a small subset of the full catalogue, shown for demonstration purposes. The entire table is provided as an <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online supplement</a></span> to this manuscript. For clarity, only the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> photometry is shown in this sample. However, in the full table magnitudes for all seven HFF bands are provided. There are approximately 300 objects in common between the two catalogues, matched within a 1\u2009arcsec radius. A majority of the matches (165 galaxies) have only a small redshift discrepancy (\u03b4<em>z</em> &lt; 0.025), agreeing well with each other given the measurement uncertainty and the lower resolution of the <em>HST</em> grism. Additionally, we find \u223c80 galaxies that have a MUSE-measured redshift but a value of \u22121 (no measurement) in the GLASS catalogue. These are almost entirely cluster-member galaxies that have strong optical absorption features that are too blue to be seen in the GLASS wavelength range. While other matches have a more substantial disagreement in their redshift values, in many cases we can compare the features seen in both the GLASS and MUSE data sets and correct misidentified features in a single catalogue. This provides a better, more accurate redshift measurement in both catalogues, and can increase the redshift confidence of a measurement made from a single, low-significance feature. In the following table, we summarize the corrections and improvements made by these comparisons, highlighting the benefits of extended spectroscopic coverage. (Only a small portion of the table is shown here. The complete table is provided as an electronic, <span class=\"link link-data-supplement\" data-supplement-target=\"sup1\"></span><span class=\"content-section supplementary-material\"><a path-from-xml=\"sup1\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/3/10.1093_mnras_stz620/1/stz620_supplemental_files.zip?Expires=1639263050&amp;Signature=lrb~nW3A9BoH0CBC2kUWe4yeGKQq84GFvqpdJFoo-HAi0sj7acTlo72Sb-9TjpsGDYPmVw-Bzg0tjus3npD4I1EIRPZ8J5V5t1r~FeyMPVJfm1eorw3sADjsV4bxeg~-wTT0jgDUcvoyq1itzvKri7ZpfyDo2y7FTulwUn1OVvtF6aCuoYFACYt7yyRCqyXYNrS2twJK9DZ0Jm-YQc6Q84MryL69ef3fiEAJ4ZYlOVPl0j5re6vXVRQuI8encw5L5Raacjm5m6ksegh-SLaiYSubzrmGsaJryiB52BpIWYQF~p4g-DfOkad1Z5Ryy7Mh8X4YsLGp77iHU5F7npjKrQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\">online supplement</a></span> to this manuscript.)</p>                        <a id=\"132763514\" scrollto-destination=\"132763514\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblD1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblD1\" data-id=\"tblD1\"><span class=\"label\">Table D1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between MUSE and GLASS redshifts (sample).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3421\u00a0</td><td>1.3399\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3613\u00a0</td><td>1.450 \u2192 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. MUSE redshift is based on a clear, bright [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] feature. Possible [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 lines seen at the MUSE redshift in GLASS G141 data, though they are noisy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4506\u00a0</td><td>1.4500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3596\u00a0</td><td>1.423 \u2192 1.450\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>], [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 identified in GLASS, but very broad. Misalignment in the wavelength solution due to variance in the grism PA makes the redshift measurement uncertain. Better resolution in MUSE removes this uncertainty.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4991\u00a0</td><td>0.8048\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3439\u00a0</td><td>0.360 \u2192 0.805\u00a0</td><td>2 \u2192 3\u00a0</td><td>Emission line at 9000\u2009\u00c5 originally identified as H\u2009\u03b1 in GLASS G102, but MUSE data reveals it to be [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>]. This is verified by additional emission lines seen at shorter wavelengths.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5109\u00a0</td><td>0.3464\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3524\u00a0</td><td>0.370 \u2192 0.346\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>Faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission seen in GLASS G102 Band misidentified as H\u2009\u03b1. The actual H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emissions match those seen in MUSE.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3421\u00a0</td><td>1.3399\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3613\u00a0</td><td>1.450 \u2192 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. Better resolution in MUSE removes this uncertainty.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4991\u00a0</td><td>0.8048\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3439\u00a0</td><td>0.360 \u2192 0.805\u00a0</td><td>2 \u2192 3\u00a0</td><td>Emission line at 9000\u2009\u00c5 originally identified as H\u2009\u03b1 in GLASS G102, but MUSE data reveals it to be [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>]. This is verified by additional emission lines seen at shorter wavelengths.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5109\u00a0</td><td>0.3464\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3524\u00a0</td><td>0.370 \u2192 0.346\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>Faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission seen in GLASS G102 Band misidentified as H\u2009\u03b1. The actual H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emissions match those seen in MUSE.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132763514\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblD1\" data-id=\"tblD1\"><span class=\"label\">Table D1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between MUSE and GLASS redshifts (sample).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3421\u00a0</td><td>1.3399\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3613\u00a0</td><td>1.450 \u2192 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. MUSE redshift is based on a clear, bright [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] feature. Possible [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 lines seen at the MUSE redshift in GLASS G141 data, though they are noisy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4506\u00a0</td><td>1.4500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3596\u00a0</td><td>1.423 \u2192 1.450\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>], [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 identified in GLASS, but very broad. Misalignment in the wavelength solution due to variance in the grism PA makes the redshift measurement uncertain. Better resolution in MUSE removes this uncertainty.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4991\u00a0</td><td>0.8048\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3439\u00a0</td><td>0.360 \u2192 0.805\u00a0</td><td>2 \u2192 3\u00a0</td><td>Emission line at 9000\u2009\u00c5 originally identified as H\u2009\u03b1 in GLASS G102, but MUSE data reveals it to be [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>]. This is verified by additional emission lines seen at shorter wavelengths.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5109\u00a0</td><td>0.3464\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3524\u00a0</td><td>0.370 \u2192 0.346\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>Faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission seen in GLASS G102 Band misidentified as H\u2009\u03b1. The actual H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emissions match those seen in MUSE.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3421\u00a0</td><td>1.3399\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3613\u00a0</td><td>1.450 \u2192 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. MUSE redshift is based on a clear, bright [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] feature. Possible [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 lines seen at the MUSE redshift in GLASS G141 data, though they are noisy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4506\u00a0</td><td>1.4500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3596\u00a0</td><td>1.423 \u2192 1.450\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>], [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 identified in GLASS, but very broad. Misalignment in the wavelength solution due to variance in the grism PA makes the redshift measurement uncertain. Better resolution in MUSE removes this uncertainty.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4991\u00a0</td><td>0.8048\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3439\u00a0</td><td>0.360 \u2192 0.805\u00a0</td><td>2 \u2192 3\u00a0</td><td>Emission line at 9000\u2009\u00c5 originally identified as H\u2009\u03b1 in GLASS G102, but MUSE data reveals it to be [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>]. This is verified by additional emission lines seen at shorter wavelengths.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5109\u00a0</td><td>0.3464\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3524\u00a0</td><td>0.370 \u2192 0.346\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>Faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission seen in GLASS G102 Band misidentified as H\u2009\u03b1. The actual H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emissions match those seen in MUSE.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div        </a></div></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostCited\">Most Cited</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n    </ul>\r\n        <section class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert \">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry at-widget-entry-SCL\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/stab2871\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/article/508/4/6111/6420626?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nOrbital parameters of the hierarchical triplet system CN Lyn    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry at-widget-entry-SCL\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/stab3132\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n<a class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.97134, \u03b4 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.5822597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf17\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf17\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>b</sup></em>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> \u2212 <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> + <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf18\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf18\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf19\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf19\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Statistics notes: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> represents the model likelihood and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {E}$|</span> the model evidence. BIC is the Bayesian information criterion. The total number of model constraints is given by <em>n</em>, while <em>k</em> represents the total number of model parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA; class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.97134, \u03b4 \u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.5822597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf17\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf17\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>b</sup></em>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> \u2212 <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup> + <em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf18\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf18\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf19\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf19\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Statistics notes: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> represents the model likelihood and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {E}$|</span> the model evidence. BIC is the Bayesian information criterion. The total number of model constraints is given by <em>n</em>, while <em>k</em> represents the total number of model parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA; 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. MUSE redshift is based on a clear, bright [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] feature. Possible [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 lines seen at the MUSE redshift in GLASS G141 data, though they are noisy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4506\u00a0</td><td>1.4500\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3596\u00a0</td><td>1.423 \u2192 1.450\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>[<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>], [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1 identified in GLASS, but very broad. Misalignment in the wavelength solution due to variance in the grism PA makes the redshift measurement uncertain. Better resolution in MUSE removes this uncertainty.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>4991\u00a0</td><td>0.8048\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3439\u00a0</td><td>0.360 \u2192 0.805\u00a0</td><td>2 \u2192 3\u00a0</td><td>Emission line at 9000\u2009\u00c5 originally identified as H\u2009\u03b1 in GLASS G102, but MUSE data reveals it to be [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small III}}$|</span>]. This is verified by additional emission lines seen at shorter wavelengths.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5109\u00a0</td><td>0.3464\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3524\u00a0</td><td>0.370 \u2192 0.346\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>Faint [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emission seen in GLASS G102 Band misidentified as H\u2009\u03b1. The actual H\u2009\u03b1 and [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{S\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>] emissions match those seen in MUSE.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>MUSE</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ID<sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>C</em><sub>GLASS</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Description<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3421\u00a0</td><td>1.3399\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>3613\u00a0</td><td>1.450 \u2192 1.340\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>Noise peak in GLASS G102 misidentified as [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm{O\\,{\\small II}}$|</span>]. a measurement having fewer than four significant digits), spectroscopic redshifts have an uncertainty \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0= \u00b10.0001. Redshifts enclosed in braces are not spectroscopic, instead fitted by the model as free parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf13\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf13\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Objects are classified according to the FF Public Modeling Challenge convention (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span>4.2.) <em>Gold</em> systems are considered the most reliable constraints, while <em>copper</em> systems are the most uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf14\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf14\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">*These systems are not used as constraints in our mass model. Our best-fitting solution merges Image 10.1 and 10.2 into a single constraint, while Image 16.2 is predicted but is not seen in either MUSE or <em>HST</em> data (see details in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span>L17).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf15\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf15\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">**While class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf12\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf12\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em>Unless otherwise specified (i.e. a measurement having fewer than four significant digits), spectroscopic redshifts have an uncertainty \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0= \u00b10.0001. Redshifts enclosed in braces are not spectroscopic, instead fitted by the model as free parameters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf13\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf13\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Objects are classified according to the FF Public Modeling Challenge convention (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span>4.2.) <em>Gold</em> systems are considered the most reliable constraints, while <em>copper</em> systems are the most uncertain.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf14\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf14\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">*These systems are not used as constraints in our mass model. Our best-fitting solution merges Image 10.1 and 10.2 into a single constraint, while Image 16.2 is predicted but is not seen in either MUSE or <em>HST</em> data (see details in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span>L17).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf15\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf15\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">**While originally identified as unique systems, updated modelling suggests they are in fact counterimages of other objects (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3-4\"></span>4.3.4).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\"
